headline: You can finally press ‘reset’ on your Instagram feed. Here’s why you should.
content: Does it ever feel like your social media feed just doesn’t get you? Or that it keeps leading your kids down unhealthy rabbit holes? You don’t have to put up with it anymore. Instagram has released a long-promised “reset” button to U.S. users that clears the algorithms it uses to recommend you photos and videos. TikTok offers a reset button, too. And with a little bit more effort, you can also force YouTube to start fresh with how it recommends what videos to play next. It means you now have the power to say goodbye to endless recycled dance moves, polarizing Trump posts, extreme fitness challenges, dramatic pet voice-overs, fruit-cutting tutorials, face-altering filters or whatever other else has taken over your feed like a zombie. Right now, many people are fed up with Instagram and its owner Meta — for filling our apps with junk, for ending fact-checking and for the behavior of its CEO Mark Zuckerberg. Resetting my algorithm made my Instagram less annoying without taking the ultimate step of deleting my account. A fresh start is also what the doctor ordered for me and my family’s mental health. I know some people love what their apps show them. But the reality is, none of us are really in charge of our social media experience anymore. Instead of just friends, family and the people you choose to follow, nowadays your feed or For You Page is filled with recommended content you never asked for, selected by artificial-intelligence algorithms. Their goal is to keep you hooked, often by showing you things you find outrageous or titillating — not joyful or calming. And we know from Meta whistleblower Frances Haugen and others that outrage algorithms can take a particular toll on young people. That’s one reason they’re offering a reset now: because they’re under pressure to give teens and families more control. (Parents of teens, see here for some more things you can do to protect your kids.) “Sometimes we make mistakes,” said Instagram head Adam Mosseri in a video announcing the reset button last year. “Sometimes you might end up in a pattern where you just make Instagram unintentionally into something you do not really love.” (Nice of him to blame us for that, rather than Instagram’s software.) So how does the algorithm go awry? It tries to get to know you by tracking every little thing you do. It’s not just likes and shares — they’re even analyzing your “dwell time,” when you unconsciously scroll more slowly over certain posts. But it doesn’t actually understand your mind. One friend, who’s the mother of a toddler, noticed her Instagram feed was being taken over with smut about parents’ desperate strategies to find private time to do the hokey pokey. Turns out, this is actually a content niche. (How have your feeds gone awry? Email me your horror stories.) For me, an Instagram account I made to share baby photos of my son turned into a fear machine when he was about a month old. It increasingly began showing images of babies with severe and uncommon health conditions, preying on my new-parent vulnerability to the suffering of children. I called for Instagram to let us press reset when I wrote about my nightmare feed in 2022. Now we finally can. What you need to know about how a social media reset works An algorithm reset isn’t the solution to all of our social media problems, but it’s better than what has come before. When you do the reset on any of your accounts, the recommended content in places like Instagram’s Feed, Explore tab and Reels or TikTok’s For You Page will no longer be tailored to your past behavior. You’ll still see content from friends and accounts you’ve previously chosen to follow. If part of your problem is that you don’t like who you’re following, Instagram will also give you the chance to unfollow a bunch as part of the reset process. Just know that once you press reset, you can’t undo it. “It’s going to make your Instagram much less interesting at first,” warned Instagram’s Mosseri when he announced the reset button. Counterpoint: You might also see “less interesting” as a good thing. The more likely you are to stop scrolling and put down your phone, the more likely you are to talk to friends, read a book or take a nap. (Free your mind, and the rest will follow.) Doing a reset also won’t stop Instagram, TikTok or YouTube from trying to recommend more content you didn’t ask for. They’re just going to start fresh and tailor your algorithm in new ways. After I pressed reset on Instagram, most of the targeted problematic content I used to see was gone. Instead, my Explore page was filled with generic Instagram trash. But I could see it trying to adapt pretty quickly, for example, offering up more dog content after I watched more dog videos. Instagram says you can send it signals for what kind of algorithm you would like by actively tapping like and watching certain content to the end. (You can also press reset again every time it starts to get annoying.) For my friend with the racy Instagram feed, she still saw “weirdly sex-oriented” content recommended after pressing reset. It’s possible that’s because Instagram was basing her new algorithm on accounts she has followed that sometimes include that kind of content. A cynical point of view is that doing a reset allows the tech companies to become even better at preying on us, because they’ll be able to test different algorithms on you. Also know that a reset won’t actually force Instagram to delete your old data — only deleting your whole account can do that. Nor will pressing the algorithm reset button do away with all of the data they use to target you with ads. For YouTube, a reset involves deleting the history of videos you’ve watched in the past. That’s one of the major signals that YouTube uses to make future recommendations. You can even turn off your YouTube history going forward, so its algorithms won’t have the data to try to interpret your interests. If you’re not ready to totally say goodbye to your algorithm, there may be other things you can do to tailor your experience. Many social media apps let you nip and tuck around the edges of your algorithm by tapping buttons to say you like or want to see more or less of certain topics. TikTok has a slider, in settings, to request more or less dance, fashion, nature or pets. On YouTube, if you click “like” on what you do like, its algorithms should listen. (Some people even turn shaping their algorithms into an art — there was one guy who crafted an Instagram that recommends nothing but eggs.) If, like me, what you really want is social media that features only the stuff you followed, you can kind of hack your way into it. There’s another Instagram setting under “Content preferences” called “snooze suggested posts in feed” that tells the app to stop recommending content there for 30 days. You just have to keep going back to press it again every month. This, sadly, is what counts as putting users “in control” these days.

headline: Argentina to withdraw from World Health Organization, following Trump
content: Argentina will withdraw from the World Health Organization, a spokesman for President Javier Milei said Wednesday, just weeks after his ally, President Donald Trump, announced he would again pull out of the global health alliance. Milei instructed his foreign minister to leave the alliance due to “profound differences regarding health management, especially during the pandemic” and “a lack of independence from the political influence of some states,” presidential spokesman Manuel Adorni said in a news conference Wednesday. “Argentines are not going to allow an international organization to intervene in our sovereignty, much less in our health,” Adorni said. The move by South America’s second-largest economy follows a Trump executive order that terminates the United States’ commitment to the organization. Trump has accused the WHO of fueling the coronavirus pandemic that helped end his first presidency and charged that it helped cover up the origins and spread of the virus. The United States is responsible for nearly 20 percent of the WHO’s funding. Public health experts warn that Trump’s departure could cripple the organization’s operations at a time when member nations are battling several dangerous outbreaks around the world and trying to stop the return of vaccine-preventable childhood diseases, such as measles. They also fear it could leave an opening for China to assume greater control over the agency that helps coordinate the response to international health crises, The Washington Post has reported. Milei, a libertarian economist whom Trump has called his “favorite president,” is one of Trump’s most important allies in Latin America. Milei attended Trump’s inauguration and has often expressed his admiration for the U.S. president. After taking office in late 2023 on a promise to take a chainsaw to government, Milei has slashed regulations, government jobs and several entire agencies. Argentina does not receive WHO funding for its health management, Adorni said, so the decision will not mean “a loss of funds for the country, nor does it affect the quality of services.” However, Adorni added, it will allow the government greater flexibility to implement policies aligned with the “interests of Argentina.”

headline: At forum, Bowser won’t rule out public funds for NFL stadium at RFK
content: On Thursday night, before a packed auditorium at Eastern Senior High School, D.C. Mayor Muriel E. Bowser (D) made it clear once again: She wants the Washington Commanders to build its next NFL home at the site of RFK Stadium, and she’s not ruling out a public subsidy to help them do it. Bowser called a football stadium “the fastest and surest route to developing the site,” a 177-acre swath of land on the banks of the Anacostia River that the city recently secured control of after years of negotiations in Congress. “Until we have a modern stadium, we will not be able to host events like the world is used to, including a World Cup, including a Super Bowl — and yes, Beyoncé and Taylor Swift,” said Bowser. The mayor’s remarks came at her largest public forum on the RFK development since the city secured control of the federal land’s destiny. The stadium was left to crumble for years because of a restrictive lease that did not allow commercial development — but after a Christmas miracle of sorts in Congress, D.C. is permitted to develop the site for multiple uses. Bowser said she plans to work with the Commanders, who now play in Landover, Maryland, to convince them D.C. is the best location and reach terms that she believes will benefit residents. Her administration will also propose plans for the rest of the site — which could include housing, a large indoor sportsplex run by the city’s parks and recreation department, and other commercial development, Bowser said. Commanders principal owner Josh Harris has avoided expressing an outright preference for the new stadium location, which will likely go in D.C. or Maryland, but he called RFK the “spiritual home” of the Commanders, took a photo with Bowser at the signing of the RFK bill at the White House, and has said D.C. is the most politically viable site. But Bowser’s vision is likely to face intense scrutiny from a divided D.C. Council and their constituents, who are not all convinced that an NFL stadium would be a good bet for city taxpayers. And in this case, city lawmakers have leverage: Any plan using public dollars will have to go through them. The question of whether taxpayer money will help fund a football stadium — and if so, how much — is shaping up to be one of this year’s largest political battles in the District. The line to get into Eastern snaked around the block as residents waited for the chance to hear the mayor make her case — and answer more than an hour’s worth of their questions. People passed out fliers, printed with the words “COMMUNITY FIRST AT RFK” and “NO BILLIONAIRE’S PLAYGROUND.” “I don’t want to see a stadium,” said Leslie Fields, 64, who has lived in D.C. for four decades. 'We’ve got people sitting in the streets. There’s a lot of things that we need to pay for. We don’t have a billion dollars lying around.” During her 20-minute presentation, Bowser argued that an NFL stadium — particularly one surrounded by housing, retail and other recreation opportunities — would bring jobs and tax revenue to the city. To support her argument, she cited a sports study she commissioned and released last year that estimated more than $1 billion in annual economic output could come from a mixed-use development with an NFL stadium. She assured residents that she envisioned much more than football at the site. With a parcel of this size, she said, “we can indeed do it all.” Some residents were all for it. “Let’s just build a stadium — Super Bowl status!” one said. Many had more tempered enthusiasm or outright skepticism. Neighboring Kingman Park residents wanted assurances they would not be displaced from their homes; Bowser promised they would not. Others wanted guaranteed opportunities for small local business owners at the site, assurances that care would be taken to avoid negative environmental impacts and promises that city leaders would be thoughtful about traffic. Skateboarders asked to be considered, hoping they wouldn’t be displaced from one of the few good places to skate in the city. A team of young pole-vaulting champions who practice nearby asked for the same. Several focused on parking. How much space would NFL stadium parking requirements actually eat up? While Bowser estimated a stadium would take up 20 to 25 acres, she would not provide an estimate for parking space. Others focused on public funding. Why fund a stadium, they asked, when the city still struggles in some cases to deliver basic resident services? Asked by one man whether she would commit to not offering the NFL team a subsidy, Bowser’s answer was unequivocal: “No.” Bowser’s presentation did not offer details about how much public money she would be willing to offer the team, only saying that her administration’s “detailed analysis” found that a stadium would be a good investment. But some wanted more details about the mayor’s economic argument, feeling uncertain that taxpayers would benefit. Some economists argue there is consensus that sports stadiums do not pay off for cities: One told The Washington Post last year that he did not even want to go into the specifics of Bowser’s sports study “because I fear going into the details grants some legitimacy to the idea that there is some debate over the economic impact of stadiums.” Last year, a Washington Post-Schar School poll found that 47 percent of D.C. residents were in favor of city funds being used for an NFL stadium and 46 percent were opposed. D.C. Council members are divided, too. Ward 2 council member Brooke Pinto (D) is shaping up to be a Bowser ally on this issue: She said last week that it was time to bring the Commanders to D.C., and that she was open to all funding options to do so — including public funding. But at least five of the council’s 12 current lawmakers — Brianne K. Nadeau (D-Ward 1), Janeese Lewis George (D-Ward 4), Zachary Parker (D-Ward 5), Charles Allen (D-Ward 6) and Chairman Phil Mendelson (D) — say they would oppose taxpayers footing the bill for a stadium. Nadeau opposes a stadium entirely, a spokesperson confirmed last week. And Allen is heavily skeptical, arguing that an NFL stadium and parking would mean sacrificing additional housing and commercial space with higher potential for full-time, year-round jobs. “I don’t think we’re having an honest conversation about what the trade-offs are,” he said in an interview last week. Five council members — Kenyan R. McDuffie (I-At Large), Anita Bonds (D-At Large), Christina Henderson (I-At Large), Matt Frumin (D-Ward 3) and Wendell Felder (D-Ward 7) — either declined to commit to a position on public financing or did not respond. Robert C. White Jr. (D-At Large) said in a statement Friday that he did not think D.C. taxpayers should foot the bill but that it would be “premature” to comment on financing for a stadium until he has seen the mayor’s full proposal. Felder, whose ward includes the RFK area, sat onstage next to Bowser at Thursday night’s forum. He spoke about a stadium as a possible economic boon for his constituents but later said he needed to see specifics before he’d decide whether taxpayer money should help fund one. “I don’t deal in hypotheticals; I need to see a proposal,” he said as he left. Penn Branch resident Jimmie Williams said he was generally supportive of an NFL stadium coming to D.C. — noting that D.C.'s loss would be another jurisdiction’s gain. But he wanted to make sure any stadium deal was done with care and an eye toward residents’ concerns. “This is an economic benefit for D.C.,” said Williams. “But it’s got to be done right.” Sam Fortier contributed to this report.

headline: More than 40,000 workers said to accept deferred resignation offer
content: More than 40,000 people have accepted the Trump administration’s deferred resignation offer, according to a person familiar with the figures who spoke on the condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to speak publicly. A day before the offer expires, the total is double what was first reported by Axios earlier this week but still less than the goal advertised by Elon Musk, the billionaire spearheading President Donald Trump’s vision for a smaller and more loyal workforce. Musk shared a post on X, his social media platform, that claimed that between 5 and 10 percent of employees eligible for the order would take it. Asked about the total, which is less than 2 percent of the civilian workforce of 2.3 million, an official with the Office of Personnel Management said the number of employees who have accepted the offer “is growing.”

headline: Johnson: House GOP to meet tonight after ‘productive’ meeting with Trump on budget
content: House Speaker Mike Johnson (R-Louisiana) said House Republicans’ five-hour meeting Thursday with President Donald Trump was “very productive,” predicting that lawmakers will soon be able to announce how they plan to advance the president’s agenda. “The president started off the meeting and sort of set the table for the discussion,” Johnson told reporters on Capitol Hill. “We’ve got out the whiteboards, and we worked out the framework for what we believe will be the path forward, and we’re going to meet again tonight to finish up some final details.” House Republicans have been working to find agreement within their ideologically divisive majority on a budget resolution that would set the fiscal parameters necessary to package Trump’s legislative agenda in one bill. Republican senators have said they intend to move forward on approving components of Trump’s agenda in two bills next week. Johnson urged GOP senators to “allow the House to do its work,” as House Republicans fret that if they do not reach an agreement, the Senate will jam them with its fiscal and policy preferences. “We are moving this as quickly and as expeditiously as possible,” he continued. “ … We’re really grateful to the president for leaning in and doing what he does best, and that is put a steady hand at the wheel and get everybody working.” White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt said Thursday afternoon that Trump outlined his tax priorities early in the meeting to lawmakers: eliminating taxes on tips, Social Security and overtime pay, as well as renewing individual portions of the 2017 Trump tax cuts, which are set to expire at the end of 2025. Nonpartisan experts estimate that the initiatives proposed by Trump will lead to a $9 trillion increase in the national debt over 10 years, which rankles fiscal hawks demanding steeper cuts in negotiations.

headline: Trump set to pull funding from schools based on race, gender teaching
content: The White House is preparing to issue a trio of executive orders on education, including one directing the Education Department to withhold federal funding from any school that teaches about “radical gender ideology” or “critical race theory,” officials said Wednesday. The order instructs the secretary of education to present a strategy to achieve this within 90 days, according to a summary. A second order promotes school choice options, including an attempt to help states use federal funding for private-school voucher programs. The third order seeks to combat antisemitism in schools. For years, Republicans including President Donald Trump have attacked schools for teaching a basket of ideas about systemic racism labeled critical race theory. Trump has also attacked schools for policies and lessons that recognize and respect transgender students. Federal law allows the agency to withhold federal funds from any school that discriminates based on race. Trump and his allies argue that lessons about systemic racism amount to discrimination, because they presume certain things about people based on race, such as that White Americans enjoy certain privileges based on their race. They say that giving rights to transgender students, especially transgender girls and women, discriminates against cisgender girls and women by forcing them to share spaces and sports teams. The order also reinstates the 1776 Commission, which Trump created just a week before the 2020 presidential election to promote “patriotic education.” The commission wrote a report that was published in the final days of his first term. The report came under heavy fire from historians as a distortion of American history, and President Joe Biden disbanded the panel as one of his first acts. As a candidate, Trump promised to reinstate the commission if reelected. Cleve R. Wootson Jr. contributed to this report.

headline: Vaccine safety panel long criticized by RFK Jr. told to postpone meeting
content: The Trump administration has directed the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to indefinitely postpone a public meeting of its vaccine advisory panel, a key forum for the nation’s discussion of information about vaccine safety and effectiveness. The decision came Thursday from officials at the Department of Health and Human Services, CDC’s parent agency, led by anti-vaccine activist Robert F. Kennedy Jr., who has long criticized the panel and the CDC. Read the full story

headline: President Donald Trump took questions in the Oval Office on Thursday, shortly after signing several more...
content: President Donald Trump took questions in the Oval Office on Thursday, shortly after signing several more executive orders on his fourth day in office. Asked for reaction on a U.S. judge temporarily blocking his executive order ending birthright citizenship, Trump said, “Obviously, we’ll appeal it. They put it before a certain judge in Seattle, I guess. Right? And there’s no surprises with that judge.”

headline: Judge says Trump officials have not complied with order to restart foreign aid
content:
A federal judge in D.C. on Thursday told the Trump administration it had failed to comply with his order to restart billions in foreign aid but stopped short of holding officials in contempt of court as plaintiffs in a pair of lawsuits had asked.
Earlier this month, U.S. District Court Judge Amir H. Ali issued a temporary restraining order blocking the administration from putting a 90-day pause on foreign assistance. In Thursday’s ruling, he said the order “was clear,” but Trump officials had not followed it.
President Donald Trump placed the aid on hold as one of his first actions after taking office in January, saying the aid did not align with American interests or values.
Health organizations filed suit in response, claiming the Trump administration was endangering the lives of many around the world who relied on the assistance to combat HIV, malaria and tuberculosis. The money also went to other development projects.
After Ali issued his temporary restraining order, or TRO, requiring Trump officials to restart the aid on Feb. 13, the administration said it had authority under other statutes to continue much of the freeze. Ali rejected that idea Thursday.
“The TRO does not permit Defendants to simply search for and invoke new legal authorities as a post-hoc rationalization for the enjoined agency action,” Ali wrote.

headline: Trump says he will fire Kennedy Center board members, appoint himself chairman
content: President Donald Trump on Friday announced plans to overhaul the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, writing that he had decided to “immediately terminate multiple individuals from the Board of Trustees,” including chairman David M. Rubenstein, in a post on Truth Social. He added that he plans to install himself as the new chairman of the prominent arts institution. He did not say which board members he plans to terminate. It is unclear whether the president has the power to make such changes. Read the full story

headline: At U.S.-Canada border, anxieties on both sides as Trump takes office
content: EMERSON, Manitoba — The U.S.-Canada border, once hailed as the “longest border of peace on Earth,” has become a flash point in bilateral relations. Like much of the 5,525-mile frontier, the line dividing this rural town from North Dakota and Minnesota is marked by few fences or imposing barriers, a testament to the close ties between the two nations. But now, President Donald Trump is threatening to impose 25 percent tariffs on Canada and Mexico, citing an “invasion” of fentanyl and migrants through its northern and southern borders as one justification. Read the full story

headline: Asked about reported Guantánamo conditions, White House says migrants there are ‘criminals’
content: When asked Tuesday about inhumane conditions described by migrants held at Guantánamo Bay over the past two weeks, White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt told reporters not to forget that they were “criminals.” The Washington Post reported earlier Tuesday that migrants held at Guantánamo Bay had said they were allowed outside once a week for an hour, forced to use a bucket as a toilet, and shackled and placed in cells described as open-air cages. When asked about The Post’s reporting about the conditions migrants are facing at Guantánamo, Leavitt said, “It’s a promise the president campaigned on — that if you invade our nation’s borders, if you break our country’s laws, and if then you further commit heinous, brutal crimes in the interior of our country … then you are going to be deported from this country, and you may be held at Guantánamo Bay.” “These are criminals we are talking about,” she added. “Don’t forget that.” Silvia Foster-Frau and Ana Vanessa Herrero contributed to this report.

headline: Trump administration details border plans, instructions to the military
content:
The incoming Trump administration said it will issue 10 executive orders regarding the border Monday.
In a call with reporters, officials described the situation on the border as “an invasion,” though a federal judge has disagreed with that characterization, and border crossings remain lower than they were when President Donald Trump left office in 2021. Among the plans:

headline: Hegseth rejects scrutiny of Trump’s Joint Chiefs pick
content: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth on Monday refused to address whether the Trump administration’s choice to become chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff is “underqualified” for the position, as concerns proliferated in Washington following last week’s firing of the military’s top officer and six other senior Pentagon leaders. “I’m going to choose to reject your unqualified question,” Hegseth told a reporter at the Pentagon ahead of a meeting with the defense secretary’s counterpart from Saudi Arabia. The question, posed by a reporter from the Reuters news agency, and Hegseth’s testy response reflected the tension sparked by President Donald Trump’s announcement Friday night that he had removed Gen. Charles Q. Brown Jr. as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff and nominated in Brown’s place a retired officer, Lt. Gen. Dan Caine, who possesses few of the qualifications detailed in U.S. law for the position. The other senior officers who were abruptly dismissed on Friday include the head of the U.S. Navy, Adm. Lisa Franchetti; the No. 2 officer in the Air Force, Gen. James Slife; Hegseth’s senior military assistant, Lt. Gen. Jennifer Short; and the top military lawyers for the Army, Navy and Air Force. The head of the Coast Guard, Adm. Linda Fagan, was fired a day after Trump’s inauguration. Retired military officers and experts on civil-military affairs have raised alarm about the firings, questioning whether Trump wants loyalists in uniform rather than nonpartisan officers. While the president is free to choose the generals he wants, they observed, the chairmanship and many other senior military positions are meant to bridge presidential administrations, providing continuity and expertise. Democrats in Congress have said the Pentagon purge endangers national security. Caine, a retired F-16 pilot and Special Operations commander in the National Guard, retired from the military in January and had moved on to a career in venture capitalism. Although he had a leadership role in the U.S. campaign against the Islamic State extremist group and later served as the senior military officer at the CIA, he has never been a service chief, Joint Chiefs vice chairman, or four-star general in charge of a combatant command. U.S. law states that a president may appoint an officer to the chairmanship “only if” they have held one of those jobs, though it notes the commander in chief can waive those requirements if he determines doing so is “necessary in the national interest.” After Hegseth’s terse response to the Reuters reporter drew attention on social media, he wrote on his official X account that Caine “is the man to meet the moment! Full stop.” Hegseth, a former Fox News host, and his team at the Pentagon have taken an increasingly aggressive posture to outside scrutiny of their moves, launching a new rapid-response account on X over the weekend that has repeatedly attacked lawmakers and journalists who have questioned their decisions. A separate White House rapid-response account called the Reuters reporter, Idrees Ali, a “Fake News loser.” That post was shared by Hegseth with his personal account and by a political appointee at the Pentagon, the deputy press secretary Kingsley Wilson, on her official government account. A spokesman for Hegseth, Sean Parnell, said in a post on X that the question about Caine’s qualifications was “inappropriate” and “demeaning to an extraordinary leader. “Dan Caine is the right man & leader for this moment & any suggestion to the contrary is just unfair," Parnell said. Ali referred questions to a spokesperson for Reuters. In a statement, the news organization said: “The question our reporter asked was timely and newsworthy.” Administration officials have defended the Pentagon firings by noting that other presidents have removed generals, pointing to the dismissals of Gen. Stanley McChrystal by President Barack Obama in 2010 and Gen. Douglas MacArthur in 1951 by President Harry S. Truman. In those cases, however, the presidents had proximate causes — McChrystal was fired after his staff disparaged Obama in an article published by Rolling Stone magazine, and MacArthur openly questioned Truman’s strategy during the Korean War. The Trump administration has offered no evidence of wrongdoing by the seven senior military leaders fired Friday, saying instead that the president wants officers more aligned with his vision. Hegseth, speaking Sunday on Fox News, said that he has “a lot of respect for CQ Brown,” calling the general an “honorable man” who was “not the right man for the moment.” Those remarks were in contrast to others Hegseth has made about Brown, whom he accused of being overly focused on diversity initiatives and had publicly mused about firing. “Dan ‘Razin’ Caine is going to be a fantastic chairman,” Hegseth said on Fox News. “I look forward to working with him, and he will give straightforward advice, as he did to President Trump on the defeat of [the Islamic State].” Hegseth also has defended his decision to fire the top military lawyers in the Army, Navy and Air Force, saying in his interview Sunday that the administration wants lawyers who give “sound constitutional advice and don’t exist to attempt to be roadblocks to anything.” Asked by another reporter on Monday to explain how the fired military lawyers had presented roadblocks, Hegseth said it was “not about roadblocks to an agenda, it’s roadblocks to orders that are given by a commander in chief.” “So ultimately, I want the best possible lawyers in each service to provide the best possible recommendations, no matter what, to lawful orders that are given,” Hegseth said. “We didn’t think those particular positions were well suited, and so we’re looking for the best. We’re opening it up to everybody to be able to be the top lawyer of those services.”

headline: Here are the words putting science in the crosshairs of Trump’s orders
content: At the National Science Foundation, staff have been combing through thousands of active science research projects, alongside a list of keywords, to determine if they include activities that violate executive orders President Donald Trump issued in his first week in office. Those include orders to recognize only two genders and roll back diversity, equity and inclusion initiatives. The search is driven by dozens of flagged words, according to an internal document reviewed by The Post and two NSF employees with knowledge of the review process who spoke on the condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to speak. Read the full story

headline: Bystander shot during robbery attempt at Waterfront Metro
content:
A bystander was shot and wounded inside the Waterfront Metro station in Southwest Washington on Tuesday night during a robbery attempt, according to a Metro spokeswoman.
The woman, who was an accidental victim, was taken to a hospital with what appeared to be injuries that were not life-threatening, the spokeswoman said.
The station, at 4th and M streets, is within two or three blocks of some of the city’s premier after-dark attractions, including the Arena Stage and the Wharf dining, residential and retail development.
It is east of the Maine Avenue waterfront, for which it is named.
Just before the shooting, which occurred a few minutes after 9 p.m., five people were involved in an attempted robbery on the mezzanine level of the station, according to the spokeswoman.
During the attempt, shots were fired and a bullet ricocheted and struck the woman.

The mezzanine level is between the street level entrance and the train platform. At the time of the gunfire, a special police officer, who was assigned to the station, was on the platform, the spokeswoman said.
In the District, special police are security guards who are authorized to carry firearms at sites where they are on duty. The officer heard the shots and notified Metro’s transit police department.
The hiring of special police to reinforce Metro’s own police department and bolster safety was reported two years ago.
Four “persons of interest” were stopped in the incident, the transit spokeswoman said. No arrests were reported and the four were not identified.
The station was closed and trains ran through it without stopping, according to the spokeswoman. It was not clear how many people may have seen or heard any part of the incident.
It apparently occurred shortly before theater patrons left the Arena after Tuesday night’s show. The Arena, on Sixth Street, is about two blocks from the scene of the incident.
According to information published online, the show, Sarah Silverman’s musical “The Bedwetter,” was scheduled to begin at 7:30 p.m. and run until about 9:10 p.m.
Metro described the investigation of the incident Tuesday night as active, and photographs showed the flashing lights of police vehicles clustered in the area.

headline: Senators ask nominees about Trump’s potential defiance of court orders
content: A Senate confirmation hearing on Wednesday for three top Justice Department lawyers was dominated by concerns from lawmakers who asked when, if ever, a president could defy a court order. Democrats and Republican Sen. John Neely Kennedy (Louisiana) made clear they think the answer should be never. But Aaron Reitz, President Donald Trump’s nominee to lead the department’s Office of Legal Policy, was equivocal on the matter. D. John Sauer, the president’s pick to serve as the government’s top advocate at the Supreme Court, was more definitive. The question was urgent, Democratic lawmakers said, as judges throughout the country have forcefully pushed back on Trump’s efforts to shrink the federal workforce, halt government spending and dismantle federal agencies. Some Trump administration officials, including Vice President JD Vance, have publicly questioned the authority of judges in response to recent rulings against some of the president’s executive orders. The administration on Wednesday was appealing a looming court deadline to pay hundreds of millions in foreign assistance funds that have remained in limbo despite a judge’s previous order. “There is no hard and fast rule in all instances in which a litigant must comply with all or some or various parts of a judicial decision,” Reitz, who is currently chief of staff to Sen. Ted Cruz (R-Texas), told lawmakers at the hearing. “It is so fact-, law- and case-specific that one cannot speak generally.” Sauer, who has represented Trump in his previous criminal cases, said, “Generally, if there’s a direct court order that binds a federal or state official, they should follow it.” As to whether Trump would defy a direct order, he said that having represented Trump for nearly two years, “I just think that’s not a plausible scenario.” In response to those answers, Kennedy offered a forceful directive to the president’s nominees: “Don’t ever, ever take the position that you’re not going to follow the order of a federal court — ever. Now, you can disagree with it within the bounds of legal ethics. You can criticize it. You can appeal it or you can resign,” he said. He separately noted his frustration with what he called efforts to undermine the legitimacy of the judiciary during the Biden administration. The committee also heard Wednesday from Harmeet K. Dhillon, a California lawyer and Republican National Committee member who is nominated to lead the department’s civil rights division. She, too, worked as one of Trump’s private attorneys. Sauer, who is nominated to serve as solicitor general, has already scored one landmark victory for Trump before the Supreme Court, winning a broad expansion of presidential immunity in Trump’s election interference case. Sen. Peter Welch (D-Vermont) invoked that court decision Wednesday when he raised concerns about the power of Congress to restrain the president’s authority, citing what he called “a profoundly new set of expectations and boundaries about what the executive power is now.” If confirmed by the Senate, Sauer would play a critical role shaping the administration’s legal strategy as it responds to a flood of litigation over Trump’s aggressive moves. Sauer, a Rhodes scholar and graduate of Harvard Law School, was a law clerk to conservative justice Antonin Scalia and another leading conservative, J. Michael Luttig, a former appeals court judge. He spent five years as a federal prosecutor before becoming the solicitor general of Missouri when the state attorney general’s office was led by Josh Hawley and then Eric Schmitt — both of whom are now Republican U.S. senators from the state. They had high praise for Sauer when they introduced him to the committee Wednesday. After he left the state attorney general’s office, he opened a small law practice instead of joining a big firm. “I don’t think John wanted to be in a position where he couldn’t do work that interested him because it conflicted with the business of the firm,” said John Demers, who worked alongside Sauer as a co-clerk to Scalia and led the Justice Department’s national security division in the first Trump administration. “He took cases he believed in, and he wanted to have the freedom to do them.” In addition to defending Trump personally, Sauer joined unsuccessful efforts to try to overturn the 2020 presidential election results and has a long track record of advocating for conservative causes. He has defended restrictions on transgender athletes in Arizona and efforts to limit access to abortion in Missouri. Sauer also helped lead litigation accusing the Biden administration of collaborating with social media platforms to censor conservative voices online. Last year, Sauer donated hundreds of thousands of dollars to Missouri Right to Life’s political action committee as it opposed a ballot measure to protect abortion rights in the state, according to Missouri campaign finance records reviewed by The Washington Post. In court, he often tangled with attorney Chuck Hatfield, who represented Planned Parenthood in Missouri in its efforts to retain funding and renew a license to operate a surgical abortion center. Hatfield called Sauer fast-talking, hardworking and incredibly bright. He also said Sauer is “not the kind of lawyer who is going to try to dissuade his client from a position that he thinks might be a stretch or inconsistent with current law.” “John is not likely to be a roadblock to policy positions his clients want to take,” said Hatfield, who earlier spent a decade working in the state attorney general’s office. “He’s more likely to be an advocate in favor of those positions — and a very good, a very smart one.” In Scalia’s chambers, Sauer stood out for his wide-ranging knowledge, outstanding memory, and ability to talk about everything from pop culture to theology and philosophy. “He’s never offensive, but he loves to argue,” Demers said of Sauer’s style. “He argues on the substance; it’s not an argument about who can raise their voice louder.” In the days before Trump’s return to the White House, Sauer continued to represent him at the Supreme Court. He tried unsuccessfully to delay Trump’s sentencing in New York for his hush money conviction and filed an unusual brief seeking an opportunity for Trump to negotiate a deal to prevent TikTok, the video-sharing app, from going dark. “President Trump alone possesses the consummate dealmaking expertise, the electoral mandate, and the political will to negotiate a resolution to save the platform while addressing the national security concerns expressed by the Government,” Sauer wrote. The brief was criticized by the Wall Street Journal editorial page and others for not staking out a legal position and suggesting that there could be more than one president at a time. Sauer’s most high-profile role came last year, when he asked the Supreme Court to rule that Trump — accused in D.C. federal court of trying to overturn Joe Biden’s 2020 election victory — should be broadly protected from prosecution for his official actions while in the White House. In response to a hypothetical question from Justice Sonia Sotomayor, Sauer suggested that it could be an official action, and therefore immune, if a president ordered the military to assassinate a political rival. The high court’s conservative supermajority ruled in favor of Trump, saying that a president’s official actions could not be prosecuted, though his private conduct could be. Luttig, who has become an outspoken Trump critic, said his former law clerk is intellectually honest and has great integrity. While Luttig disagreed with the court’s immunity ruling, he said Sauer made the only possible argument that could save Trump from criminal prosecution. “A man who can convince the Supreme Court that the Constitution affords the President of the United States absolute immunity can convince the Supreme Court the Constitution means anything he wants,” Luttig said. “That the Supreme Court bought the fallacious argument hook, line and sinker was not to Mr. Sauer’s discredit. It was to the Supreme Court’s discredit.” All three nominees seemed to have the support they would need from Republicans to advance to the full Senate. As head of the Justice Department’s civil rights division, Dhillon would oversee an office whose work traditionally has included investigating police misconduct, enforcing voting rights and filing cases over alleged civil rights violations. If confirmed, she would be the first Sikh American to hold the position. Dhillon has previously garnered attention for her legal work targeting social media companies, challenging corporate diversity policies, and suing over California’s pandemic restrictions. Reitz, a Marine Corps veteran who previously worked for Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton (R), would oversee a Justice Department office tasked with advising the attorney general on policy and assisting in the selection of nominees for the federal bench. Democrats repeatedly confronted him Wednesday with his past posts on the social media site X, many of which have been deleted. One post from March 2020 responded to a ruling from U.S. District Judge Lee Yeakel temporarily blocking Texas from closing an abortion clinic during the covid pandemic. “Judge Yeakal has made his decision. Now let him enforce it,” Reitz wrote, echoing an apocryphal quote attributed to Andrew Jackson in response to a much earlier court ruling. He was asked at multiple points during Wednesday’s hearing to commit to the concept that even the president should be bound by adverse court rulings. Reitz repeatedly resisted giving a firm answer. “My position reflects a fairly mainstream view within right-of-center jurisprudential circles, which is simply to suggest that various Supreme Court or Court of Appeals decisions are more limited in scope than maybe our friends who share a different jurisprudential view of Supreme Court holdings would suggest,” he said. Sen. Cory Booker (D-New Jersey) pushed back. “You’re not giving me great confidence by not stating unequivocally that we are a nation that respects the separation of powers, the role of the courts and … the traditions of the country,” he said. Razzan Nakhlawi contributed to this report.

headline: Can you find all the Oscar statues? Try our image search.
content:
We all know winning an Oscar is hard, but finding them on a disorganized and messy movie set might be harder. With the help of illustrator Max Guther, we hid 23 Oscar statues, one per category, and 17 Easter eggs for nominated films. Can you find them all before the Academy Awards show on Sunday? Test your skills below. (Psst, you can zoom in for a better view.)
About this story
Editing by Betty Chavarria and Junne Joaquin Alcantara. Copy editing by Emily Morman.

headline: DOGE staffer Marko Elez resigns after report on racist social media posts
content: A 25-year-old staffer who was granted access to the Treasury Department’s sensitive payments system has resigned after the Wall Street Journal surfaced his racist and pro-eugenics posts, a person familiar with the matter said. Marko Elez, who was working at Treasury but was affiliated with billionaire Elon Musk’s U.S. DOGE Service, resigned after the Journal unearthed his posts. “Just for the record, I was racist before it was cool,” his account posted, the Journal reported. Elez was one of two people affiliated with DOGE that a federal court allowed to access the Treasury system, which is responsible for disbursing more than $5 trillion in annual payments. The person familiar with the matter spoke on the condition of anonymity to describe internal government matters. Elez worked for Musk at SpaceX, Starlink and X, according to the Journal.

headline: Arab leaders scramble for alternative to Trump’s Gaza proposal
content: President Donald Trump’s plan to remove Palestinians from the Gaza Strip and create a real estate “riviera” on the eastern Mediterranean has spurred a regional scramble for an alternative, with Arab leaders working on a proposal that aims to pump billions of dollars in reconstruction money into the enclave, according to people familiar with the planning. Leaders from Jordan, Egypt, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Qatar met in the Saudi capital, Riyadh, on Friday to thrash out details less than three weeks after Trump laid out a plan for the United States to “take over” Gaza and displace the population there, a proposal that has been broadly condemned as tantamount to ethnic cleansing. The emerging Arab plan would call for Palestinian technocrats to govern Gaza and the provision of substantial funds to rebuild the shattered enclave, where the vast majority of the population of 2 million has been left homeless, according to five people with knowledge of the discussions. And while details of the plan are still being hashed out, they say there is resounding unanimity on one issue: Palestinians should not be displaced. “The Trump proposal is so outlandish and offensive to many in the Middle East that certainly it’s a nonstarter. It’s a hot mess,” said Sen. Richard Blumenthal (D-Connecticut), who has discussed plans with regional leaders including Jordan’s King Abdullah II, whom Blumenthal met in the Jordanian Red Sea resort of Aqaba this week. “The Arab plan will seek to present a realistic proposal for reconstruction in Gaza without forced evacuation and without a United States takeover,” Blumenthal said in a telephone interview. The broad strokes of the Arab plan — hoped to be finalized ahead of an emergency summit with representatives of the broader 22-member Arab League on March 4 — are “becoming clearer,” Blumenthal said. But significant hurdles remain, including reaching Arab consensus and obtaining U.S. and Israeli buy-in, he added. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has said that Israel is “committed” to Trump’s plan and described it as a “bold vision” for Gaza. The proposal has also received rapturous approval from the country’s far-right politicians, who have pushed for Israeli settlements in Gaza and the enclave’s annexation. But Arab states are hoping to garner backing for their plan with their checkbooks. A new assessment by the United Nations estimates that it could cost $50 billion to rebuild Gaza after the devastation caused by 15 months of war. The exact figure to be put forward is “still up for review,” but the proposal is likely to include a headline number, said Emirati academic Abdulkhaleq Abdulla, a visiting fellow at Harvard University. “The number is important because they know the president of the United States is transactional, he likes numbers, and they think he might be swayed when he sees these billions of dollars,” including construction opportunities for U.S. companies, he said. Egyptian Prime Minister Mostafa Madbouly said this week that regional construction firms, including those in Egypt, have the capacity to build 300,000 housing units over a three-year period. Other proposals being considered appear aimed at keeping Trump’s interest in investment at the heart of Gaza’s future. One, from the Al Habtoor Group, an Emirati conglomerate, outlines a phased approach that would establish security in the territory and transition emergency housing into redevelopment over 18 months. Arab countries know they hold leverage by being “the ATMs” for reconstruction, said Brian Katulis, a senior fellow at the Middle East Institute. However, the “clash of worldviews,” between Israel and Trump on one side and the region on the other, remains a major sticking point, he said. During his trip to Washington this month, Netanyahu looked on smiling as Trump outlined his plans for a U.S. “takeover” of Gaza. “The big impediment is if the whole exercise will be accepted by Trump, and certainly big questions over whether it will be accepted by the current Israeli government,” Katulis said of the Arab plan. Phase one of the Arab plan envisages reconstruction in areas that have not been completely obliterated, but Arab leaders are willing to open their wallets only if other political and security elements of a plan are put in place, said Sen. Chris Van Hollen (D-Maryland), who has recently met with ministers from Egypt, Saudi Arabia, Qatar and Jordan to discuss evolving plans. “It’s a delicate balancing act because all these three pieces need to converge,” he said. The technocratic committee envisioned for Gaza under the Arab plan would not include Hamas, the ruler of Gaza for almost two decades and architect of the Oct. 7, 2023, attack on Israel. “The two main driving principles on the governance side is that Hamas will have no governing role in Gaza, and also that it creates a political unity with the West Bank,” said Van Hollen, adding that Arab states want the Palestinian Authority, the governing entity in the West Bank, to have some degree of sign-off on the structure. Arab leaders, like previous U.S. administrations, have long advocated a clear path to a two-state solution, which Netanyahu has repeatedly opposed, along with any rule by the Palestinian Authority in Gaza. “Squaring that circle is a big challenge at this point,” Van Hollen said. Two officials briefed on the plans, who spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss sensitive proposals that are still in flux, emphasized that the technocratic government is intended to be a “temporary” body to oversee rebuilding and would remain in place only until elections could be held. While many officials in Abu Dhabi, the UAE capital, and in Riyadh remain frustrated that they were not informed before Trump floated the Gaza displacement plan, they also acknowledge that the U.S. leader’s approach has succeeded in motivating the Arab states to act, according to the officials. “Trump scrambled the table, and it forced other people to start doing some of the heavy lifting,” said one individual familiar with the thinking of the regional leadership. Others in the region draw parallels to Trump’s comments on Ukraine that spurred emergency meetings of leaders in Europe. But Van Hollen said he also fears that Trump’s plan has set back the chances of making a deal. “In addition to being outrageous on its face, it’s further emboldened the far right and made it more difficult to achieve an overall settlement,” he said. Hamas’s objections are another potential spoiler to any plan, as is the thorny question of who will provide security in Gaza. Hamas still holds weapons stockpiles, while the security vacuum has led to a rise in criminal gangs. “There is still a very challenging and complicated road ahead, even if Arab leaders present a realistic plan,” said Blumenthal, adding that Abdullah has been “very clear-eyed and realistic” in his thinking. But while the gaps remain wide, both Trump and Netanyahu want a normalization deal between Saudi Arabia and Israel, and also to maintain a regional coalition against Iran as Israel mulls strikes against Tehran’s nuclear program. “There is a golden opportunity for Israel to integrate with the region and recognize its wildest dreams,” said Katulis. While Trump’s initial proposal to empty Gaza of its inhabitants sparked anger in Saudi Arabia, the close ties between the two powers were on full display this week. Trump made an appearance at a Saudi investment summit in Miami after tapping Riyadh to host talks to end the war in Ukraine. The coverage in Saudi media was glowing. Saudi Arabia “has achieved success on all fronts,” proclaimed a column in Asharq al-Awsat by Tariq Alhomayed, the newspaper’s former editor. Speaking at the summit in Miami on Thursday, Steve Witkoff, Trump’s special envoy to the Middle East, addressed Gaza and appeared to dial back elements of the president’s plan that had caused alarm, saying some of Trump’s comments had been misconstrued. The level of destruction is so great, a five-year development plan “is not physically possible,” he said. “That doesn’t mean we are on an eviction plan,” he said. “It means the president wants to shake up everybody’s thinking.” Witkoff said Arab leaders are now considering new solutions for rebuilding Gaza, ideas that “people would have never considered, and I think that’s a good thing.” Abigail Hauslohner in Washington contributed to this report.

headline: Trump shuts off access to asylum, plans to send 10,000 troops to border
content: President Donald Trump is preparing to send 10,000 troops to the southern border, and Border Patrol agents have been directed to deny entry to asylum seekers if they “traveled through a country with communicable disease,” according to a U.S. Customs and Border Protection briefing document obtained by The Washington Post. The order does not list any specific disease, essentially closing the border to anyone attempting to exercise the right to seek humanitarian refuge under U.S. law. Read the full story

headline: Trump appoints loyalists to Kennedy Center board
content: President Donald Trump was officially elected chair of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington on Wednesday, installing a new board of trustees as he furthers his executive authority to remake one of the nation’s premier cultural institutions. The Kennedy Center’s new board is composed of Trump loyalists, including White House Chief of Staff Susie Wiles, White House Deputy Chief of Staff Dan Scavino, second lady Usha Vance, former transportation secretary Elaine Chao and Trump himself, according to its website. “It is a Great Honor to be Chairman of The Kennedy Center, especially with this amazing Board of Trustees. We will make The Kennedy Center a very special and exciting place!” Trump posted on Truth Social, noting he was voted in as chairman unanimously. Trump’s recasting of the Kennedy Center board breaks from tradition. The arts venue has typically been led by a bipartisan board and evenly split between Democratic and Republican appointees to ensure diverse programming. On Monday on Truth Social, Trump also named former acting director of national intelligence Richard Grenell, who is serving as an envoy for special missions, as the interim executive director of the Kennedy Center.

headline: President Donald Trump signed an executive order Monday creating the “Department of Government Efficiency” led by...
content:
President Donald Trump signed an executive order Monday creating the “Department of Government Efficiency” led by his billionaire adviser and donor Elon Musk. The executive order was expected to create a DOGE office within the White House, although Trump had initially said the panel would exist outside the government.
Musk will have an office in the White House with about 20 people, Trump said Monday. Trump said DOGE’s White House office would help ensure the executive actions would get implemented.

headline: Attorney General Pam Bondi called the corruption charges against New York City Mayor Eric Adams “the...
content:
Attorney General Pam Bondi called the corruption charges against New York City Mayor Eric Adams “the weaponization of government” during a CPAC talk. She accused prosecutors of bringing charges to “make deportation harder.”
“It’s about ending their weaponization of the government and fighting violent crime and enabling cities like New York and mayors like Eric Adams to enforce Donald Trump’s immigration policies,” Bondi said.

headline: HUD moves to cancel $1.1 billion in already-awarded housing upgrades
content:
The Department of Housing and Urban Development, acting on a directive from DOGE, is moving to terminate more than $1.1 billion in loans and grants awarded to improve the energy efficiency and weather resilience of multifamily housing, according to a department official with knowledge of the order.
The termination of the Green and Resilient Retrofit Program puts into jeopardy more than 260 projects across the country, several of which have already begun construction. The projects were expected to create “hundreds, if not thousands of jobs” according to the department official. “It’s unfortunate that they are targeting such an effective program just because it has the word ‘green’ in its name,” the official said.
The department communications office did not respond to questions from The Washington Post. The move is likely to spark legal challenges, as the congressionally authorized funds were already awarded by the department, which is now trying to claw them back.
The program, created through the 2022 Inflation Reduction Act, is targeted at upgrading subsidized housing units. It is designed to help building owners and residents lower their utility bills by using less energy, as well as help fund improvements such as fire-resistant roofs and new heating systems that will prolong the life of the units.
“This program helps to rehabilitate affordable apartments, making sure residents have lower utility costs and can survive extreme weather,” said Lowell Ungar, federal policy director for the American Council for an Energy-Efficient Economy. “You disrupt that and it means higher bills for those who can least afford them and greater risk from storms and heat waves.”

headline: FAA targeting Verizon contract in favor of Musk’s Starlink, sources say
content: The Federal Aviation Administration is close to canceling a $2.4 billion contract to overhaul a communications system that serves as the backbone of the nation’s air traffic control system and awarding the work to Elon Musk’s Starlink, according to two people briefed on the plans. The move to cancel a major contract in favor of a venture led by Musk — who is leading President Donald Trump’s disruptive overhaul of the federal government through the U.S. DOGE Service — would represent a significant test of protections against conflicts of interest in government projects. It would be an especially extraordinary step for the typically cautious FAA, whose systems are vital to the safety of millions of air travelers every day. The existing contract was awarded to Verizon in 2023, with the aim of upgrading a platform that different air traffic control facilities and FAA offices use to communicate with one another. Musk has personally taken aim at Verizon on his social media platform X in recent days, saying on Monday: “The Verizon system is not working and so is putting air travelers at serious risk.” Verizon did not respond to a request for comment. Joseph Russo, a Verizon executive vice president, said at an event hosted by Barclays Bank on Tuesday that Starlink’s efforts at FAA might be complementary to Verizon’s. Verizon was offering the “reliability and performance” that the FAA needed, and its system was expected to be operational soon, Russo said. The FAA said in a statement Wednesday that “no decisions have been made” about the Verizon project. A team of employees from SpaceX, Starlink’s parent company, has been working inside the FAA in recent days, charged by the Trump administration with helping modernize the agency’s aging technology. Ted Malaska, one of them, shared a picture on X on Thursday saying he was excited to be working with the FAA, and thanking Musk and Trump for their “vision and focus on safety.” “I challenge anyone to question the honesty and my technical integrity on this matter,” Malaska posted Wednesday. “I am working without biases for the safety of people that fly.” Several of the SpaceX employees now have FAA email addresses, according to two people who have seen the addresses, speaking on condition of anonymity for fear of retribution. FAA regulates SpaceX and has alleged that the company has violated safety rules relating to its rocket launches. In a statement Monday, the FAA said it was testing Starlink systems at facilities in New Jersey and Alaska, in hopes of providing more reliable connectivity in remote locations. Elements of the FAA’s deliberations were previously reported by the Associated Press and Bloomberg News. Transportation Secretary Sean P. Duffy said on Fox News this week that the government had been too slow to modernize its technology and that the new administration was ready to move quickly. “We’re going to look at a year, year-and-a-half time frame and do massive upgrades, improve the systems, help air traffic controllers, keep our skies safer,” Duffy said. But the Starlink plan adds to Musk’s existing conflicts of interest at the FAA relating to SpaceX, according to John P. Pelissero, the director of an ethics center at Santa Clara University. Pelissero said it appears that “because of Musk’s current position in DOGE and his closeness to Trump he and his company are getting an advantage and getting a contract.” “Who’s looking out for the public interest here when you get the person who’s cutting budgets and personnel from the FAA, suddenly trying to benefit from still another government contract?” Pelissero said. The Transportation Department, DOGE and SpaceX did not respond to questions on how the process of changing contractors has been handled and whether potential conflicts of interest have been reviewed. Trump has said Musk will not be permitted to participate in decisions that pose a conflict of interest. Verizon was tapped in 2023 to build a system called the FAA Enterprise Network Services Program or FENS, replacing a system that dates to 2002. The contract had a 15-year lifespan, and the system is intended to connect some 4,600 sites, according to the FAA. The agency was scheduled to make a final decision on whether to start paying Verizon for the contract next month, said one of the people, who spoke on the condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to speak publicly. Instead, Musk’s team determined the job should go to Starlink, the person said. But the process for unwinding a contract and awarding it to another company is lengthy and has not been followed in this case so far, the person said. Several senior FAA officials have refused to sign paperwork authorizing the switch, according to the person, who has been briefed on the internal deliberations and resulting fallout, so Musk’s team is now seeking help from the acting administrator of the agency, Trump appointee Chris Rocheleau, and Duffy. Outside reviews of the FAA’s technology have repeatedly concluded in recent years that it is woefully out of date and that the agency is too slow to make upgrades. A 2023 safety review pointed to technological problems as one factor that was creating “risk” in the aviation system, a problem the Verizon contract is supposed to help solve. Jessica Tillipman, the associate dean for government and procurement law studies at George Washington University School of Law, said terminating a contract can be expensive, time consuming and could lead to litigation. “When the government terminates a contract it’s not like it shuts off the spigot,” she said. “It’s expensive to wind down a contract. It’s very expensive and it’s complicated.” She said negotiating a settlement can take a year. In awarding a new contract, agencies must comply with the Competition and Contracting Act, which requires competition in government procurements. It does have some exceptions. Among those: national security, public interest or urgency, she said. “But the question is, how is it so urgent when you already had a contractor dealing with it?,” said Tillipman, adding that there are many different guardrails within the federal acquisition system to make sure things are fair, transparent and efficient. “However, in the last few weeks she said many of these guardrails have been tested, which will likely lead to litigation,” she said. Washington Post researcher Aaron Schaffer contributed to this report.

headline: Trump: Government will sell $5 million ‘gold card’ to wealthy immigrants
content: President Donald Trump said on Tuesday that the United States will soon sell a $5 million “gold card” to give foreign nationals “green card privileges” and a “route to citizenship.” Trump made the announcement during an executive order signing in the Oval Office, telling reporters, “Wealthy people will be coming into our country by buying this card.” “They’ll be spending a lot of money and paying a lot of taxes and employing a lot of people, and we think it’s going to be extremely successful,” Trump said, claiming that the program — which he said will begin in about two weeks under his executive authority and without the approval of Congress — is “totally legal.” Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick told reporters in the Oval Office that the Trump administration will be ending the controversial EB-5 investor visa — sometimes referred to by critics as the “golden visa.” The citizenship pathway created in 1990 requires significant investments in a new business that would create full-time jobs in the United States. Lutnick said the $5 million requirement for the “gold card” would be paid “to the U.S. government” and applicants would require “thorough vetting.” Lutnick suggested the money would be used “to reduce our deficit,” but Trump would not definitively state whether that money would be earmarked specifically for deficit reduction. The president said that if “gold card” holders create jobs within the United States, “they’ll pay full taxes like everybody else.” Trump also said he anticipated that the card would be used by American companies seeking to bring in talent from abroad. When asked whether Russian oligarchs would be eligible for a “gold card,” Trump responded, “Yeah, possibly. I know some Russian oligarchs that are very nice people.”

headline: Trump says administration looking at sending criminals out of country
content:
“Numerous countries” have offered to imprison U.S. citizen criminals, President Donald Trump said Tuesday, and “if we have the legal right to do it, I would do it in a heartbeat.”
For “a small fee compared to what we pay” in government-run and private prisons in this country, he said, “we can make deals where we get these animals out of our country.”
He said his administration was examining the legality of such action.
Trump’s comments, made in response to questions from reporters witnessing his signing of new executive orders at the White House, came after Salvadoran President Nayib Bukele said this week that he would imprison U.S. criminals for payment.
“We have hardened criminals, horrible people, you see them pushing people into subways,” Trump said. “We don’t want these people in our country. … These people are never going to be any good.”
If they are sent out of the country, he said, “you would have a lot less crime automatically.”

headline: Pentagon says ‘identity months’  like Black History Month are ‘dead’
content: Shortly after President Donald Trump signed a proclamation celebrating National Black History Month on Friday, the Pentagon issued guidance declaring that “identity months” were “dead” within the Defense Department. Trump’s proclamation acknowledged the contribution of several history-making Black Americans, calling upon “public officials, educators, librarians, and all the people of the United States to observe this month with appropriate programs, ceremonies, and activities.” But Friday’s guidance from Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth specifically states that the Pentagon will no longer “use official resources, to include man-hours, to host celebrations or events related to cultural awareness months, including National African American/Black History Month, Women’s History Month, Asian American and Pacific Islander Heritage Month, National Hispanic Heritage Month, National Disability Employment Awareness Month, and National American Indian Heritage Month.” The memo added though that employees, including service members in the military and civilians, could attend such events outside of their work time. “We are proud of our warriors and their history, but we will focus on the character of their service instead of their immutable characteristics,” the memo says.

headline: U.S., Ukraine near deal to grant mineral rights to Washington
content: The Trump administration and the Ukrainian government were nearing a deal Friday to hand Ukrainian mineral resources over to the United States in exchange for continued security assistance, a person familiar with the negotiations said, potentially easing President Donald Trump’s days of attacks against the embattled country and its leadership. Read the full story

headline: Trump to build mass detention camp for deportees at Guantánamo Bay
content: President Donald Trump said he will order the construction of a mass detention camp that can hold 30,000 deportees at the Guantánamo Bay Naval Base, outlining plans Wednesday for the largest U.S. facility of its kind. Speaking at the White House before signing the Laken Riley Act, a bill that is expected to expand the number of immigrant detainees held in U.S. custody for minor property crimes, Trump said the massive camp would “detain the worst criminal illegal aliens threatening the American people” and be “a tough place to get out of.” Read the full story

headline: Trump ends with a bold promise for a ‘golden age’
content: President Donald Trump ended his speech on an optimistic note about the future of the United States, while making a dig at his predecessor by asserting that the “nation has suffered greatly” in recent years. “We will be a nation like no other,” he said. “Full of compassion, courage and exceptionalism. Our power will stop all wars and bring a new spirit of unity to a world that has been angry, violent and totally unpredictable.” Trump has not yet specified what his plan is to end the war in Ukraine, which he promised to stop during his tenure. Biden officials involved in arranging the ceasefire and hostage-release agreement in the Middle East acknowledged that Trump and his Middle East envoy, Steve Witkoff, played a role in bringing the deal across the finish line. Trump shocked the political establishment at his first inauguration by straying from the formula for these speeches, painting a dark picture of “American carnage.” On Monday, he again presented a negative view of the current state of affairs, but he ended on a far more traditional tone that acknowledged the ambition and success of Americans. “We will dream boldly, and nothing will stand in our way because we are Americans,” he said. “The future is ours and our golden age has just begun.”

headline: Pope shows ‘slight improvement’ amid special prayers at St. Peter’s
content: VATICAN CITY — Pope Francis remained in critical condition Monday as the Vatican held the first nightly rosary recitation in St. Peter’s Square, underscoring concern over the 88-year-old pontiff’s health. There was some measure of positivity Monday night. The Vatican said that Francis, who has been suffering from double pneumonia, showed “a slight improvement” over the course of the day and after a restful night. He had no further asthmatic episodes, and some laboratory tests had improved, it said. As thousands of people converged on St. Peter’s Square, Cardinal Pietro Parolin, the Vatican’s secretary of state, called on prayer to support Francis “in this moment of illness and trial and help him to recover his health soon.” Vatican officials said this was the first time in their recollection that a special saying of the rosary had been held for Francis. Under a steady drizzle, priests, nuns, religious pilgrims and Romans recited the rosary inside the colonnaded square. Cardinals and senior clerics sat at the top of the stairs in front of St. Peter’s Basilica. The altar consisted of a gold-framed depiction of the Virgin Mary cast against the evening darkness under a white canopy. Attendees were somber as they prayed, some visibly moved. “The pope is the most important person in the world for us,” said Wiestow Piosecki, 43, an IT specialist from eastern Poland. He brought his wife and three children to Rome for the jubilee and were devastated when the pope fell ill. “His voice is important, especially with the war in Ukraine. I feel afraid now, afraid he may die. I feel my prayer can help.” Due to the complexity of his clinical picture, the pope’s doctors at Rome’s Agostino Gemelli Polyclinic Hospital were still not prepared to offer a prognosis. In the morning, Francis received Holy Communion, and he worked in the afternoon and was eating solid food. In the evening, he called the parish priest in Gaza whom he has spoken with almost daily throughout the war to offer his “paternal closeness.” Francis, the Vatican said, also offered thanks to those who have gathered in recent days to pray for his health. A mild renal insufficiency disclosed on Sunday, the Vatican said, was not “cause for concern.” The pope’s oxygen therapy continued, although with slightly reduced flows and percentage of oxygen. Francis’s health crisis stretched into the end of its 10th day, making this the longest of his four hospitalizations as pope. Some senior clerics spoke in stark terms over the weekend about his chances. The hospital chaplain said Monday that it was time “to hope against hope.” In recent days, Catholic churches around the globe, including in Francis’s native Argentina, have prayed for the first New World pontiff. On Sunday, Cardinal Baldassare Reina, the vicar general of the Diocese of Rome, held a Mass for the pope, while encouraging other pastors in the diocese to do the same. The saying of the rosary during a papal health crisis is seen as a spiritual gesture to pray for an especially ailing pope. In 2005, Cardinal Leonardo Sandri, then the undersecretary of state for the Vatican, announced the death of John Paul II to the crowds gathered in St. Peter’s Square after they finished saying the rosary for him. Giovanni Maria Vian, a former editor of the Vatican’s newspaper and a historian of early Christianity, said the St. Peter’s event on Monday night for Francis also reminded him of a saying of the rosary before the passing of Pope John XXIII in 1963. “I’m sure numberless such rosaries have been said at Gemelli,” he said. “This [event] feels closer to the prayers in St. Peter’s Square when [John Paul II] and [John XXIII] were dying, back in 2005 and 1963. I was there as a boy, and later [as an adult].” In the upper echelons of the Roman Catholic Church, speculating on the health of a pope has long been delicate terrain. But some senior clerics have offered surprisingly candid assessments. On Saturday, Cardinal Timothy Dolan of New York said, “We’ve got to be kind of realistic. … It’s not looking good.” Francis’s doctors have sought to convey more optimism, suggesting his life is only at risk if he develops serious complications. Talk of his condition is partly due to the pope’s own quest for transparency. His doctors say he has insisted on offering only the “truth” to the public, and the extent of the medical disclosures has been unusual for the Vatican, which is traditionally guarded about a sitting pope’s health. Francis was admitted to the hospital with a respiratory tract infection on Feb. 14. Late Tuesday, the Vatican said CAT scans had revealed the pope to have double pneumonia. Chest X-rays showed he had developed a polymicrobial infection that arose from asthmatic bronchitis and bronchiectasis, a condition in which the airways widen, leading to a buildup of excess mucus that can make the lungs more vulnerable to infection. It said he was undergoing a “complex” treatment using antibiotic cortisone therapy.
