The Bulldogs played a rigorous nonconference schedule, at times taking their lumps in the name of preparing for these moments. They contended with injuries and roster turnover, relying on new leaders to prosper and younger pieces to blossom. Each time, the Bulldogs answered the call. A 14-4 run to end the first quarter was Saturday’s answer.
“There are times when being a high school basketball coach is the best job in America, and knowing what these boys have been through, just staying together and trusting me, it’s just a great feeling,” Bullis’s Bruce Kelley said.
From the second quarter on, the game felt destined to come down to the final shot — and it did. Georgetown Prep had possession with eight seconds left, trailing by two. The ball worked its way to five feet beyond the top of the key. The final seconds were ticking off the clock, and the Hoyas’ attempt was on the way to the rim. Kelley could have sworn it was going in.
But the shot bounced off the iron, and the game was over. Queen’s “We Are the Champions” soon blared from the gym’s speakers. The Bulldogs wouldn’t dare tempt the basketball gods by practicing the ritual beforehand, meaning they finally could climb a stepladder to cut down the nets.
“That was the greatest feeling I’ve ever had,” freshman Xavier Skipworth said. “Coach always says we have to be a fist and not separate fingers. We knew they were going to punch hard, but we just had to stick together. We just did that.”

headline: In the lead-up to President Donald Trump’s inauguration, mentions of “oligarchy” among prominent left-wing politicians and...
content: In the lead-up to President Donald Trump’s inauguration, mentions of “oligarchy” among prominent left-wing politicians and influencers surged nearly tenfold, according to a Washington Post analysis. Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vermont) revived the term in response to reports about Elon Musk heading a new commission focused on government spending. The discussion intensified after President Joe Biden’s farewell address Jan. 15, when he warned of an emerging oligarchy and a powerful tech-industrial complex in America.

headline: Trump says he wants to send ‘repeat offenders’ in U.S. legally to foreign countries
content:
DORAL, Fla. — President Donald Trump said Monday that he doesn’t just want to deport undocumented immigrants with criminal convictions, but also hopes to remove violent, repeat offenders — in the United States legally — from the country.
“I don’t want these violent repeat offenders in our country any more than I want illegal aliens from other countries who misbehave,” Trump said at House Republicans’ retreat at his Doral golf club. “And I say — and this is subject to getting it approved — but if they’ve been arrested many, many times, they’re repeat offenders by many numbers, I want them out of our country.
“I also will be seeking permission to do so,” Trump continued, musing: “Let them be brought to a foreign land and maintained by others for a very small fee.” He complained about the cost of keeping inmates in the United States.
Trump did not provide more details about his plans, and it is not clear how he would seek to carry them out.

headline: Trump reinstates plan to strip protections from federal workers
content: President Donald Trump on Monday reinstated a policy to strip employment protections from tens of thousands of federal workers, potentially allowing his administration to reshape agencies by stocking them with political loyalists. The executive order was one of multiple first-day Trump directives aimed at overhauling the federal workforce of 2.3 million — including a hiring freeze, a strict return-to-office mandate, an update of hiring rules and changes designed to bring more accountability to career senior executives, in part by making them easier to dismiss. Read the full story

headline: Analysis: Parsing the latest Pete Hegseth allegation
content: President Donald Trump’s defense secretary nominee, Pete Hegseth, in his Senate confirmation hearing last week dismissed a series of allegations against him as “anonymous smears.” But not all of them have been anonymous. And now, for the second time, Hegseth has been accused of abusive behavior toward women by a woman named Hegseth. Read the full story

headline: Six girls, 11 to 14, arrested in assault outside Union Station
content: A total of six girls, ages 11 to 14, have been arrested and charged in an “egregious” and apparently random attack on a woman by a group of youths outside Union Station, according to the D.C. police. Two of the girls, ages 11 and 13, were arrested Thursday, the police said. The other four girls were arrested Friday, according to police. Their ages were similar to the first two: they were given as 11, 12, 13 and 14. The first indication of a possible motive in the attack was given Friday. It may have been motivated by prejudice, the police said in a statement Friday night. “Detectives’ investigation revealed the suspects potentially being motivated by hate or bias,” the statement said. As a result, police said, all six suspects have been charged with assault with a dangerous weapon with an enhancement related to an alleged hate crime. The type of prejudice was not specified. An earlier statement, reporting the first two arrests, said nothing about possible hate or bias or any other motive. Authorities said one of the participants recorded and posted the assault on social media. One of the youths repeatedly kicked and punched the woman, dragged her by the hair “and encouraged the other suspects to continue their attack,” according to a police statement and a report. No serious injuries were reported, police said Friday. The incident occurred Sunday but was not reported to police, who said they learned of it Wednesday when they were alerted to videos on the internet. Police have said they were looking for as many as nine girls in the attack. “The actions of these young suspects are disturbing and deeply disheartening for all of us who care for the youngest people in our community,” D.C Police Chief Pamela A. Smith said in a statement after the first two arrests. “There is absolutely zero tolerance for this behavior in our city. Harming our community like this will result in your arrest and prosecution, no matter your age.” The attack in Northeast Washington is reminiscent of the deadly assault in 2023 by five girls ages 12 to 14 on Reginald “Reggie” Brown, a frail and disabled 64-year-old man who had been on a stroll that his family said he took to cope with the strain of cancer treatments. One of the girls recorded the beating, and another testified in court that she and her friends had been “bored” and were looking for someone to beat up. All were found criminally responsible in juvenile court and sent to the city’s youth rehabilitation agency. That incident shocked authorities for its brutality and for the ages of its attackers. It occurred during a year in which violent crime soared in the District and when youths, as both victims and offenders, were of high concern. In the attack outside Union Station on Massachusetts Avenue, the assailants assaulted bystanders who tried to intervene, police said. They said the first two girls were charged as juveniles with assault with a dangerous weapon, conspiracy to riot, simple assault and disorderly conduct. In addition to the assault charge, those located and arrested Friday were also charged with rioting, the police statement said. In their original statement, police also said they were collaborating with counterparts in other jurisdictions to determine whether the youths could be connected to similar attacks elsewhere. Those other areas were not identified.

headline: Federal board halts firings of six probationary employees amid Trump cuts
content: An independent federal board on Tuesday granted a request from the U.S. Office of Special Counsel (OSC) to halt the termination of six probationary government employees amid the Trump administration’s efforts to slash the federal workforce. The move by the Merit Systems Protection Board (MSPB) was in response to a recent request issued by OSC head Hampton Dellinger, in which the watchdog agency argued that the firings were probably illegal and recommended that they be halted pending an investigation, The Washington Post reported. The MSPB, which hears appeals of disciplinary actions against federal employees, said Tuesday that the request for a 45-day stay of the terminations was appropriate “while OSC further investigates their complaints.” Legal organization Democracy Forward, which filed a complaint on behalf of the six workers Feb. 14 alongside the Alden Law Group, said Tuesday in a statement that the two groups will now work “to expand the stay to cover all probationary federal employees who were unlawfully terminated.” Democracy Forward president and CEO Skye Perryman called MSPB’s decision “the correct result of a clearly unlawful and massively disruptive action by the Trump administration.” The White House did not immediately respond to a request for comment on the decision. The MSPB’s move could have wider implications for the thousands of probationary employees fired in recent weeks as the Elon Musk-led U.S. DOGE Service sweeps through federal agencies. Probationary employees, who are newer hires and typically have less job protection, were targeted in cuts earlier this month, and government agencies are in the process of firing thousands more workers. Dellinger is “considering ways to seek relief for a broader group,” OSC said in a statement Monday, while worker advocates hope an investigation could end with a remedy for all fired federal workers. OSC, which investigates whistleblower reports filed by government workers, is tasked with investigating and prosecuting complaints about prohibited personnel practices in the federal workforce, such as retaliation or rule-breaking, that violate the merit system. President Donald Trump has tried to oust Dellinger and MSPB chair Cathy Harris as he looks to remake and seize greater control of the federal bureaucracy. Both have sued the Trump administration over their firings, saying their terminations violate federal law, and have been temporarily reinstated by district judges in D.C. In the Feb. 14 complaint, the six workers allege they were fired during “plainly unlawful” mass terminations that were “indisputably conducted with no regard for the performance or conduct of individual probationary employees.” The six employees were terminated around the same time as at least 5,000 or more other probationary workers in their agencies, according to estimates cited in Dellinger’s request. They worked for the Departments of Veterans Affairs, Education, Energy, Housing and Urban Development, and Agriculture, as well as the Office of Personnel Management. Dellinger found that the employees had not been given notice of any specific issues with their job performance or conduct before being fired. He concluded that the agencies may have violated federal regulations governing how to reduce a workforce or how to terminate probationary employees. “Firing probationary employees without individualized cause appears contrary to a reasonable reading of the law, particularly the provisions establishing rules for reductions in force,” Dellinger said in the Monday statement. Alden Law Group partner Michelle Bercovici said in a statement that Tuesday’s decision “reflects the importance of the MSPB and OSC in safeguarding the fundamental merit system principles and most importantly, allows these wrongfully terminated employees to return to their jobs, provide for their families, and continue serving the public with dignity and integrity.”

headline: President Donald Trump signed an executive order on Monday requiring the federal government to return to...
content: President Donald Trump signed an executive order on Monday requiring the federal government to return to the use of plastic straws and away from paper straws. “We’re going back to plastic straws. These things don’t work,” Trump said from the Oval Office. “I’ve had them many times, and on occasion, they break, they explode.”

headline: Trump freezes hiring for many federal jobs
content:
The White House issued a freeze on the hiring of civilian employees across the government Monday night, exempting active-duty military personnel and positions related to immigration enforcement, national security and public safety. The order also prohibits the use of outside contractors to get around the freeze, a strategy used by previous administrations to maneuver around hiring caps.
The order also appears to open the door for the permanent federal personnel reductions that President Donald Trump campaigned on. Within 90 days, the administration is directed to come up with plans to “reduce the size of the Federal Government’s workforce through efficiency improvements and attrition.” Then the hiring freeze will be lifted.
The exception is the Internal Revenue Service. The freeze will remain in place there until Trump officials “determine that it is in the national interest” to lift it.

headline: Sen. Amy Klobuchar (D-Minnesota), the chairwoman of the bipartisan Joint Congressional Committee on Inaugural Ceremonies, said...
content:
Sen. Amy Klobuchar (D-Minnesota), the chairwoman of the bipartisan Joint Congressional Committee on Inaugural Ceremonies, said in opening remarks that there was “a reason” that the ceremony takes place at the U.S. Capitol.
“In other countries, it might be in a presidential palace or a gilded executive office building. Here, it is traditionally held at the Capitol, the People’s House,” she said. “It is a fitting reminder of the system of checks and balances that is the very foundation of our government. Three equal branches of government.”

headline: Trump spoke with Saudi crown prince in first call with foreign leader
content: President Donald Trump spoke Wednesday with Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, his first call with a foreign leader since he was sworn in as president again. During the call, Mohammed said he wanted to pour $600 billion into trade and investments with the United States, according to the official Saudi Press Agency. They also discussed ways to promote stability in the Middle East and to combat terrorism. The White House confirmed that the call occurred but has not yet provided details about the discussion. Trump had a close relationship with the de facto Saudi ruler throughout his first term, and his first foreign trip was to Riyadh. In 2018, Trump expressed his strong support for Saudi Arabia, effectively ignoring the CIA’s conclusion that Mohammed ordered the brutal killing of Washington Post contributing columnist Jamal Khashoggi in Istanbul.

headline: Losing is the Wizards’ way. It might also be their way out.
content: The Washington Wizards are in the middle of one of the worst seasons in NBA history. They won just nine of their first 54 games before the all-star break and have the worst record in the NBA, 3½ games behind the New Orleans Pelicans. The season extends the franchise’s struggles in the 21st century: The Wizards have the lowest winning percentage of all franchises since Jan. 1, 2000. They also haven’t won at least 50 games in a season — the mark of a very good but not great team — since 1978-79. The Wizards had been run by Ernie Grunfeld or his top lieutenant, Tommy Sheppard, since 2003. They broke away from that tree after the 2022-23 season in an organizational overhaul. Washington hired former Los Angeles Clippers general manager Michael Winger as the president of Monumental Basketball, the group overseeing the Wizards, the WNBA’s Washington Mystics and the G League’s Capital City Go-Go. Winger brought in General Manager Will Dawkins, who previously worked with Winger with the Oklahoma City Thunder. Weeks after the two were hired, they began an intense rebuild that included trading stars Bradley Beal and Kristaps Porzingis. An oversimplified description of Washington’s new strategy: Lose a lot, get high draft picks, accumulate young talent, and develop it into a winning core. The Wizards won just 15 games in 2023-24. They’re on pace for even fewer this season and have often lost by wide margins. Until recently, they were en route to having the worst average point differential in NBA history. A recent positive stretch (more on that later) has bumped them up to third worst. Winger and Dawkins have overseen two drafts in D.C. They have made four first-round picks, including three last year, and acquired another rookie this month in the Kyle Kuzma trade. The Wizards haven’t been shy about playing their youth, believing in-game repetitions — going through the fire, as Coach Brian Keefe often puts it — is the best way to develop. Injuries to Kuzma and guard Malcolm Brogdon early this season increased the young players’ minutes and roles. The development process often has been ugly — as evidenced by two 16-game losing streaks, each tying the franchise record. Washington almost always has multiple players on the court who have yet to reach their physical primes or maximize their skills — players who are often committing youthful mistakes and undergoing growing pains. The Wizards have the NBA’s worst offensive and defensive ratings (points scored and allowed per 100 possessions), per Basketball Reference. Those young players seem to be improving, an increased comfort somewhat evident in the Wizards’ recent positive stretch. In February, the team jumped to 11th in offensive rating and 21st in defensive rating, per analytics site Cleaning the Glass. The month even featured a season-best three-game winning streak. But Wizards fans probably don’t want to see their team win too much over the final 28 games. Though the NBA flattened the lottery odds so the three worst teams have the same chance at netting the No. 1 draft pick, finishing worst means that team can fall only as far as fifth. This season undoubtedly has been painful, evident in the red on all of these graphs. Winger, Dawkins and the rest of the organization hope the short-term struggles lead to a high draft pick and eventually the type of sustainable winner that has been absent in Washington for nearly 50 years.

headline: Acting ICE director removed amid White House pressure to boost arrests
content: The Trump administration has removed the top official at Immigration and Customs Enforcement one month into his tenure, as White House officials have become increasingly frustrated that the agency isn’t arresting immigrants fast enough to satisfy the president’s deportation goals. Caleb Vitello, a veteran ICE official who was installed as acting director when President Donald Trump took office, will be reassigned to a senior role overseeing daily enforcement operations, according to Department of Homeland Security spokeswoman Tricia McLaughlin. She did not say who would replace him. Trump has ordered ICE to carry out the largest mass deportation campaign in U.S. history and quickly ramp up the number of immigrants it arrests each day. Despite the administration dedicating a rush of resources to the effort that has included sending thousands of troops to the southern border and assigning thousands of agents and officers from the FBI and other federal law enforcement agencies, ICE’s budget and staffing remain largely unchanged, leaving officers scrambling to meet aggressive arrest quotas. In late January, Vitello told ICE’s 25 field office directors they should arrest at least 75 immigrants per day for a national daily total of 1,200 to 1,500. ICE officers have been working six and even seven days a week since then, but Department of Homeland Security Secretary Kristi L. Noem and Trump “border czar” Tom Homan have blamed agency officials for falling far short of those goals. Homan did not respond to requests for comment. Louisiana Secretary of Wildlife and Fisheries Madison Sheahan, a former campaign aide to Noem, is expected to become acting deputy director of ICE, according to two people familiar with the matter who spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss a position that hadn’t been publicly announced. Sheahan was also executive director of the South Dakota GOP. A DHS official said that “positions are being reevaluated” and that the agency had “nothing new to announce at this time.” ICE averaged more than 800 arrests per day nationwide in late January in the 10 days after Trump took office, publishing its results on social media amid a publicity campaign that invited television crews to embed with officers. The pace of arrests slowed during the first two weeks of February to fewer than 600 daily, and ICE stopped publishing data on social media, saying it would move to a monthly format. Current and former ICE officials said the enforcement blitz in late January depleted the lists of targets ICE developed before Trump took office with the names, addresses and other data on immigrants they could arrest. Officer teams have not had time to build out new target lists. Officers have also struggled to meet their quotas because many immigrants are refusing to open their doors when ICE officers knock, according to three ICE officials. Noem has accused FBI agents of leaking sensitive information about upcoming immigration enforcement operations, which the law enforcement agency has pushed back on. The enforcement teams generally do not possess criminal arrest warrants that would allow them to force their way into their targets’ residences. ICE officials say they can’t afford to leave teams of officers waiting for targeted immigrants to leave their homes. Vitello’s demotion follows the reassignment this month of the top two officials at ICE’s enforcement division. A Trump administration official said that Vitello will now oversee field and enforcement operations as part of an effort to expand the team. The official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss the personnel move, said Noem made the decision and it was not done at Trump’s direction. Vitello’s removal was first reported Friday by The Wall Street Journal. Several ICE staffers said news of his demotion caught them by surprise, and they found out through news alerts. Jason Houser, chief of staff for ICE under President Joe Biden, said that the White House is asking ICE to “defy the math” and do things that are “unrealistic.” “The White House needs to look in the mirror,” Houser said. “The dysfunction isn’t with ICE rank-and-file who are trying to do their jobs effectively.” The Trump administration has sought to take an all-of-government approach to immigration enforcement, treating it as a near wartime effort. At least 3,600 servicemen and servicewomen have been sent to the border, according to the Defense Department. The administration has used military planes to transport migrants to locations as far away as India. As ICE has run out of space in its detention centers, the Trump administration has started to send migrants to the Guantánamo Bay Naval Base in Cuba, where Trump ordered the construction of a detention camp with 30,000 beds. On Thursday, 177 Venezuelan migrants at Guantánamo were deported to their homeland. Homan has said he is “not happy” with the results so far. Senate Budget Committee Chair Lindsey Graham (R-South Carolina) said recently that Homan came to the Hill “begging” for additional money. The Senate adopted a budget blueprint early Friday for legislation to increase border security and immigration enforcement by $175 billion. Trump has backed a competing, more expansive plan in the House. The Biden administration deported 271,000 people in fiscal year 2024, the highest annual total in a decade. Deportations during Trump’s first term reached a peak of about 267,000 during the 2019 fiscal year, even as he made similar promises. ICE would need to deport more than 2,700 people a day to hit 1 million deportations a year, a goal that veteran immigration officials say is improbable.

headline: President Donald Trump on Monday touted his weekend threat to levy tariffs on Colombia after they...
content: President Donald Trump on Monday touted his weekend threat to levy tariffs on Colombia after they turned away deportation flights — and said his actions should send a message to other nations. “As you saw yesterday, we’ve made it clear to every country that they will be taking back our people … and they’re going to take them back fast,” Trump said at the House Republicans’ Florida retreat. “And if they don’t, they’ll pay a very high economic price. And we’re going to immediately install massive tariffs.” Trump also reiterated his love of the word “tariff” — which he joked was his fourth favorite word in the dictionary, after “God,” “love” and “religion.”

headline: Trump appoints leader of his Secret Service detail to head agency
content: President Donald Trump said Wednesday that he is appointing Sean Curran — the special agent in charge of Trump’s security detail who shielded him during an assassination attempt at a Pennsylvania campaign rally last year — to serve as the next U.S. Secret Service director. “Sean has distinguished himself as a brilliant leader, who is capable of directing and leading operational security plans for some of the most complex Special Security Events in the History of our Country, and the World,” Trump wrote in a post on his social media platform, Truth Social. “He proved his fearless courage when he risked his own life to help save mine from an assassin’s bullet in Butler, Pennsylvania. I have complete and total confidence in Sean to make the United States Secret Service stronger than ever before.” Curran is widely respected for his rigor and skills as a protective detail agent and supervisor, growing extremely close to Trump after serving as the agent in charge of his detail for the past four years. It was Curran, however, who approved assigning a junior detail agent with minimal experience to prepare the security plan for the campaign visit to Butler, a plan that failed to address basic security protocols and allowed a would-be assassin a clear shot at Trump from higher ground. Trump’s appointment of Curran will hearten some longtime agents but also ignores the recommendations of multiple expert panels who have studied the Secret Service’s security failures and recommended fresh leadership from outside the agency. Trump is following a long line of presidents before him by naming a key member of his protection team as the agency’s director, rather than choosing someone outside the Secret Service to give it fresh leadership who can revamp and harden its approach to protection.

headline: Senate Democrats plan 30-hour protest of Vought’s nomination for OMB
content: Senate Democrats plan to protest the confirmation vote of Russell Vought to lead the Office of Management and Budget by holding the Senate floor for the full 30 hours of debate that are allowed before a final vote Thursday. Democrats will speak overnight about what they see as the dangers of Vought’s vision for reducing federal spending through freezing and reviewing funds. Vought, who has warned that the government is “woke and weaponized” and has said federal workers should be viewed as villains, is emerging as a new opponent for Democrats given President Donald Trump’s aggressive moves to overhaul and diminish some federal agencies. He is expected to be confirmed Thursday on a party-line vote.

headline: Judge allows intelligence agencies to fire officers in DEI roles
content:
A federal judge on Thursday refused to stop the CIA and director of national intelligence from firing 51 officers who had been assigned to diversity, equity, inclusion and accessibility roles that were scrapped last month by President Donald Trump. The officers may not appeal to civil service boards, and they may not transfer to other jobs in the intelligence community because agency rules allow the director to fire employees without any recourse.
In three court hearings this month, U.S. District Judge Anthony J. Trenga questioned why the Trump administration decided to fire all of the officials instead of reassigning them, as had been recommended by career-services officials at the CIA and the Office of the Director of National Intelligence.
“These are talented, experienced assets, if you will, that would be in the interests of the United States to be reassigned elsewhere, if that need existed,” Trenga said at a hearing Monday in U.S. District Court in Alexandria, Virginia.
But government lawyers said CIA Director John Ratcliffe relied on a regulation particular to the intelligence community stating that “any employee may be terminated from the Agency at any time without regard to any procedural steps … when the [director], in his discretion, deems it necessary or advisable in the interest of the United States.” Assistant U.S. Attorney Dennis Barghaan said that prevented the employees from being reassigned.
Kevin T. Carroll, a lawyer for the fired officers, argued that “in the interest of the United States” meant that the employee was being fired for reasons related to national security, and that there should be individualized findings before anyone is released. But Trenga said the court didn’t have jurisdiction over an administrative claim unless the agency waived its sovereign immunity, and that the officers probably wouldn’t prevail on the issues that their First Amendment right to free speech and their Fifth Amendment right to due process were violated.
“In effect, they are at-will employees,” the judge ruled. “The regulations make it clear they have no property interest in the employment they have.”
As the disappointed officers looked on, Carroll said afterward: “We respect the court’s decision. I would certainly hope, given the judge’s remarks, that Director Ratcliffe would consider allowing the plaintiffs to apply for other jobs.” He said one of the fired officers had eight other job offers within the CIA, as a data scientist, but was prevented from accepting one.
The lawsuit was filed by 19 anonymous intelligence officers who said they had been temporarily assigned to DEI roles within their agencies and were now being scapegoated “in the service of a partisan ideological agenda.” Some of the employees have been on the job for two decades, according to court records. Ten of the employees were in court for Thursday’s ruling, but declined to comment afterward.
Earlier, Carroll said the career intelligence officers had been trained at taxpayers’ expense to perform some of the most sensitive spy jobs — “from source development to recruitment” and “collection to analysis” — and that they were being fired despite being qualified for other open positions at their agencies. Some stand to lose the government pensions they had been working toward for years, the lawyer said.
“None of these officers’ activities was or is illegal, and at no time have the agencies employing Plaintiffs contended that they individually engaged in any misconduct, nor are they accused of poor performance,” Carroll said in a legal filing. Their job duties included “advancing the hiring, promotion and advancement of members of protected classes,” and firing them for performing assigned work would violate their constitutional rights, he said.
According to court records, the officers were placed on administrative leave with pay two days after Trump signed an executive order last month terminating all DEI programs in the executive branch. Weeks later, some of the officers were told to report to their agencies’ visitor centers with their badges and without lawyers. That’s what it looks like when an intelligence community member is about to get fired or placed on leave without pay, one of the anonymous CIA officers said in a court filing.
The intelligence officer defended the need for diversity among the agency’s ranks. Blending in “racially and culturally” among foreign populations is key to intelligence collection, he said. “There are needs for dual citizenship documentation, foreign language skills and/or overseas living experiences,” the officer said, noting that in some cultural settings, women will not meet alone with men.
Justice Department attorneys said in a legal filing that Director of National Intelligence Tulsi Gabbard had not finalized any plans to fire officers in DEI roles. But Gabbard and Ratcliffe have unqualified authority to fire any of their employees, and Ratcliffe has chosen to use it, the attorneys argued.
Ratcliffe in a court filing said he could terminate any CIA employee under provisions of the National Security Act of 1947, “when, in my discretion, I deem it ‘necessary or advisable in the interests of the United States.’ ” Shutting down the CIA’s diversity and inclusion office and firing all its employees met that standard, he said.
The DEI-related firings could affect not just the 19 intelligence officers who sued but a total of 51 employees at the CIA and Office of the Director of National Intelligence, their attorneys said. At the CIA, they said, the mass ouster “suggests an unlawful effort … to misuse the Director’s unique national security-related authorities to evade federal equal opportunity laws.”
Trenga said he was puzzled by the CIA’s decision not to reassign the officers. Agency regulations state that any employees who are terminated as part of a downsizing should be offered open positions, he said. Justice Department attorneys said Ratcliffe fired the employees under a different regulation that provides no such job protections.
“I frankly don’t quite understand why that’s being resisted by the agency,” the judge said at the hearing Monday. Trenga was appointed to the bench by President George W. Bush and presides over the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court in addition to serving as a federal district court judge in Virginia.
Attorneys for the CIA officers said the agency’s career service has identified at least one suitable open position for each of them.

headline: Native leaders warn that freezing of federal funds could imperil some services
content:
Native American leaders said they’re worried about the impact of a freeze on federal grants and loans that could affect dozens of programs that provide a range of services including food, health care, education, housing and law enforcement.
The United States has more than 570 federally recognized tribes, and many receive some type of funds to provide programs and services for their tribal citizens through the federal government.
Advocates and leaders in tribal communities said they’re concerned that many tribes are not in a financial position to fully fund their citizens’ needs without federal money.
“Everybody is scrambling in Indian Country,” said Brian Weeden, chairman of the Mashpee Wampanoag Tribe in Massachusetts, which has about 4,000 enrolled citizens and whose tribe receives grant funds from the federal government.
“Tribes are trying to figure it out,” he said, “and draw down programs to make sure they can stay afloat.”
Josh Arce, president and chief executive of Partnership with Native Americans — a nonprofit group that provides services and aid to more than 150 tribal communities in remote areas of the Southwest and northern plains — said “we’re pretty surprised” about the freeze.
“It’s not something we thought we’d wake up to on a Tuesday morning,” he said, “and it could impact so many things for Native American communities, from road and bridge programs to childhood education and nutrition efforts for the elderly.”
Arce said some tribes use the federal grants for much-needed services, and “if they don’t have the ability to offset the loss, we don’t know what that could look like for continuing essential programs or starting new programs for the year.”
“That means communities that have basic needs could see those needs go unmet,” he said. Programs that pay for firewood or propane gas to heat homes or distribute food could be hurt, he said.

headline: ‘Interviewing two brothers:’ Trump, Musk speak about relationship
content:
Seated side-by-side on prime-time television, President Donald Trump raved about Elon Musk’s intellect and business acumen to Fox News host Sean Hannity, insisting during a joint interview that their relationship is thriving as they seek to reshape the federal government together.
“Well, I respect him,” Trump said. “I’ve always respected him. I never knew that he was right on certain things, and I’m usually pretty good at this stuff.”
Trump said he “wanted to find someone smarter than him,” but “couldn’t do it.”
The interview comes amid mounting outside scrutiny of Musk’s role within the White House — and whether his fate will resemble past outspoken advisers Trump booted in his first term.
Referring to the world’s richest man as “actually a very good businessman,” Trump said that Musk has ensured that his flurry of executive orders are being enforced, but steered clear of saying Musk was the brains behind any of them.
“He gets it done,” Trump said. Musk, for his part, described himself as “tech support” for carrying out Trump’s executive orders.
“I feel like I’m interviewing two brothers here,” Hannity said.

headline: Suit charges violation of Privacy Act as DOGE accesses personal data
content:
A coalition of labor unions and individuals filed suit in federal court Monday alleging that Elon Musk and the U.S. DOGE Service have been given access to sensitive records of millions of American in violation of the Privacy Act.
The suit alleges that DOGE staff who do not have appropriate security clearances or vetting have been given access to personal information at the Education Department, which has private information of 43 million student borrowers; the Treasury Department, whose records include information on every American who receives a tax refund or Social Security benefit; and the Office of Personnel Management, which has personal information for every federal employee.
The suit was filed by the American Federation of Teachers, the National Active and Retired Federal Employees Association, the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers and the National Federation of Federal Employees. Several individuals are also named as plaintiffs.
“Defendants are permitting Elon Musk and a cadre of loyalists imported from his private companies to help themselves to the personal information of millions of Americans” in violation of the Privacy Act, the suit charges. “Steamrolling into sensitive government record systems threatens to upend how these critical systems are maintained and compromises the safety and security of personal identifying information for Americans all across the country. It also violates federal law.”

headline: Judge briefly extends order barring Trump from firing watchdog leader
content: A federal judge on Wednesday extended for three days an order preventing the Trump administration from firing the head of an independent watchdog agency that has sought to pause President Donald Trump’s mass termination of some probationary federal workers. U.S. District Judge Amy Berman Jackson said she wanted more time to consider the lawyers’ arguments before issuing a broader ruling on whether the administration’s attempted ouster of Hampton Dellinger, the head of the Office of Special Counsel, was unlawful. A temporary restraining order barring Dellinger’s firing will remain in place until Saturday, she said. Dellinger, an appointee of President Joe Biden, sued the administration after he received a one-sentence email earlier this month telling him he was fired from the office, which protects government whistleblowers. He said his termination violated a law that says the president can remove him only for “inefficiency, neglect of duty, or malfeasance.” Jackson on Feb. 12 ordered him reinstated for two weeks while his case proceeds. The Trump administration argues that the Constitution allows Trump to remove Dellinger and other agency leaders. On Tuesday, an independent federal board granted a request by Dellinger to halt the administration’s firings of six probationary government employees. Dellinger said the firings of those employees, and potentially many others, were probably illegal. In court Wednesday morning, Jackson sharply questioned claims by the Trump administration’s lawyer that Trump had the power to fire Dellinger without cause and that the law prohibiting him from doing so was unconstitutional. Unlike other agency heads, the special counsel was granted independence from the president to investigate potential wrongdoing by the administration, the judge said. Dellinger was appointed to a five-year term that ends in 2029. “His actual job is to be a check and balance on the president,” Jackson said. The judge pressed Justice Department lawyer Madeline McMahon to explain why it would be in the public interest to fire Dellinger. McMahon said barring Dellinger’s removal would cause Trump to “lose control over an executive branch agency” and would represent an “intrusion” into Trump’s authority under the Constitution.

headline: Snow and slush didn’t dampen street style at New York Fashion Week
content: NEW YORK — When I was sent to photograph New York Fashion Week in September 2024, many people I spoke with were shocked to hear it was my first time. I’ve been working as a photographer for 25 years, but in this arena, I felt something like an alien. Coming back this week for a second time was more familial. One word that comes to mind, to sum it all up, is community. It’s remarkable, and to state the obvious — beautiful — to see the art of garments, hats, shoes and accessories, celebrated with such reverence and a kinship among fashion fans and favorites. February’s fashion seemed extra chilly with a dash of snowflakes. I had hoped to get images of models in the streets as several inches of snow fell, but that didn’t happen with much of the snow coming overnight. But the slick, slushy sidewalks were not enough to keep people from showing up in their finest. Sure, most of these folks were headed inside to witness the latest designs come down the runways. But the real circus is indeed outside of these events. Dozens of fashion editors, models, designers, stylists and even the want-to-be-seen parade down the streets — sometimes even stopping traffic. I saw amateur and professional photographers turning their lenses on fashionistas in the middle of intersections as motorists angrily honked their horns. This is where all the action is. I’m highly attracted to the fun chaos of it all. Folks proudly sashaying down alleys. People wearing garments of all kinds — some they made themselves. The funniest accessory I saw at a fashion show was a cheetah-printed bong, and the model had the pants to match. It is indeed a community, an eclectic one at that.

headline: President Donald Trump on Wednesday said he wanted the Department of Education to be “closed immediately.”
content:
President Donald Trump on Wednesday said he wanted the Department of Education to be “closed immediately.”
“Look, the Department of Education’s a big con job,” he said in the Oval Office.

headline: After under-the-radar retool, D.C. United hopes to ‘prove people wrong’
content: D.C. United spent the offseason acquiring more than a dozen players, accounting for about half the roster. The goalkeeping corps is new. An Aussie center back arrived from Scotland, a Brazilian winger via Poland. Five newcomers are expected to start Saturday night’s opener against Toronto FC at Audi Field. Why, then, does it feel as if United did not accomplish much this winter? Perhaps because, unlike many teams around MLS, United did not make any blockbuster trades or sign a high-priced international player. Instead, it acquired three players who missed most of last season with injuries and four who toiled most, if not all, of 2024 in the second division. Two other acquisitions were MLS backups. Three came from overseas with modest fanfare, another through the college draft. “For those that have that perception, that’s understandable,” United Coach Troy Lesesne said of the restrained activity. “We’ve signed some players that may not carry that type of [big] name but are very talented themselves. They fit our game model, and we believe in them, and we hope that D.C. United is going to be a platform for them to take off in their career.” United has one of MLS’s biggest names: captain Christian Benteke, MLS’s scoring champion. He is D.C.’s only designated player — the label for talent that exceeds salary cap restrictions and requires ownership to pay mostly out of pocket. Each team is allowed to employ up to three DPs. United’s second slot remains filled by team assists leader Mateusz Klich, even though he is no longer on the roster. Though he was traded to Atlanta, most of his contract remains on United’s books. Although Lesesne and his players are upbeat, United failed to generate any offseason buzz in MLS circles. Accordingly, preseason predictions have D.C. missing the playoffs for the sixth consecutive year and finishing at or near the bottom of the 15-team Eastern Conference. “You want to be the team that’s looked at as the big dogs in the league. You want to be one of the favorites and have that privilege of having the target on your back,” all-star right back Aaron Herrera said. “But at the same time, we’re realistic with ourselves. We saw what we did last year and where we ended up. So how do we expect to be [higher in] anyone’s prediction? We’re here to prove people wrong.” Since Lesense and General Manager Ally Mackay took over before the 2024 season, the roster has been gutted. Benteke and injured midfielder Jackson Hopkins are the only players remaining from the 2023 opener. This year’s squad features not only 13 newcomers but four holdovers who either arrived deep into last season or missed most of the year with injury. Returning center back Lucas Bartlett has a new partner: Australia’s Kye Rowles, a 2022 World Cup starter who played the past 2½ years for Hearts in Scotland. The new starting goalkeeper is Kim Joon Hong, a 21-year-old South Korean. Hosei Kijima, a rookie midfielder for St. Louis City last year, drew rave reviews from teammates in the preseason. Costa Rican Randall Leal (Nashville) and Brazilian João Peglow (Polish league) also hope to bolster the attack. Brazilian playmaker Gabriel Pirani, in his second full season in Washington, is aiming for a breakout year after showing bright signs late last season. Lesesne will also need players to show improvement after mixed performances last year. “When I look at myself, I’m not saying I wasted a year, but as a young player, every year you want to take big steps forward,” said Matti Peltola, a 22-year-old midfielder. “If I’m not going to be able to take big steps forward this year, then I’m really looking [in] the mirror, big time.” With some roster space and cap flexibility, United could continue to make changes until the initial roster deadline April 23. The summer transfer window, which opens in July, typically offers an abundant international marketplace. “We created a good group,” Benteke said. “Even though I’m the captain [and] I’m the leader, I believe the star of the team is going to be the group because the way we want to play, we will need all of us.” Lesesne has retained a high-pressure style designed to force turnovers and create immediate opportunities. In the preseason, he implemented a plan that also won’t rely as heavily on Benteke (23 goals) and will generate a wider variety of chances. “It’s in constant evolution and improvement,” Lesesne said. “If you watched us in preseason, you could see, ‘Okay, they’re trying to go for something a little bit different.’” Defensively, United will need to tighten up not only in its own end but in transition. Last year, teams often unlocked D.C.’s press and capitalized on open space. United conceded 70 goals, third most in MLS and second most in club history. “The intensity of the press is still going to be the same,” Herrera said. “But there’s a couple different pieces, couple different moving parts.” United will also need to improve its home performance after ending 2024 in a 1-6-5 rut at Audi Field and 4-8-5 overall. The team will play three of its first four matches at Buzzard Point, and none of those four opponents had a winning record last year. While championship aspirations seem far-fetched, Lesesne and the players say they see promise after narrowly missing the playoffs last fall. (The front office also sees promise: To entice former season ticket holders to return, United promised a 30 percent rebate if the team fails to make the playoffs.) “We were competitive last year, and we started to show ourselves in terms of the proof of concept was there,” Lesesne said. “We want to build on that, but we have to take a bigger step this year. I don’t want to be around this position of nine, 10, 11 [in the standings] and just be in the mix. I’d like us to take a step forward.” D.C. United roster

headline: ‘Post Next 50’ Debuts, Highlighting People Shaping Society in 2025
content: “Post Next 50,” a project profiling 50 individuals set to shape society in 2025 and beyond, launched this week. Produced by The Washington Post’s Special Initiatives & Partnerships (SIP) team, it featured multiple feature formats, dynamic off-platform storytelling, and a bespoke print product. The initiative highlighted a wide range of honorees, each carefully evaluated by reporters and editors with subject-matter expertise to confirm their potential to drive meaningful change. “Our focus was on looking forward, not honoring past achievements,” said Evan Bretos, Senior Director of Special Newsroom Initiatives and Partnerships. “Post Next 50 shines a spotlight on individuals whose work will shape the future, offering fresh perspectives on important issues.” This initiative reinforced The Post’s commitment to expanding its reach and engaging audiences across multiple platforms. “Post Next 50” also marked the first initiative under WP Ventures, showcasing how newsroom-wide collaboration can drive impact. 50 profiles of those expected to make an impact this year on an interactive landing page with moving portraits “Post Next 50” featured multiple multimedia experiences, including two episodes of our flagship Post Reports podcast, a dedicated print magazine edition, and eight social-first videos. The package also included a methodology video explaining the selection process. To commemorate the inaugural list, The Post hosted an intimate gathering to recognize the honorees, with Post Executive Editor Matt Murray, Chief Advertising Officer Johanna Mayer-Jones, Editor of WP Ventures Krissah Thompson, WP Ventures General Manager Samantha Henig, and Senior Director, Special Initiatives & Partnerships Evan Bretos. Guests from the Post Next 50 List included, Dr. Kizzmekia Corbett-Helaire, Grégoire Courtine and Jocelyne Bloch, Kara Valvert, Vinod Balachandran, Jeff Jenkins, and more. You can find more information and experience “Post Next 50” here.

headline: Under the original planning document for the inauguration ceremony, Supreme Court Justice Brett M. Kavanaugh was...
content: Under the original planning document for the inauguration ceremony, Supreme Court Justice Brett M. Kavanaugh was supposed to be swearing in JD Vance as vice president at 11:32 a.m. Eastern time. The event is running  behind schedule, by perhaps 30 minutes or so.

headline: President Donald Trump, early on in his speech, offered strong criticism of the current government while...
content:
President Donald Trump, early on in his speech, offered strong criticism of the current government while former president Joe Biden and former vice president Kamala Harris sat behind him.
“We now have a government that cannot manage even a simple crisis at home, while at the same time stumbling into a continuing catalog of catastrophic events abroad,” Trump said. “It fails to protect our magnificent law-abiding American citizens, but provides sanctuary and protection for dangerous criminals, many from prisons and mental institutions that have illegally entered our country from all over the world.”
“From this moment on, America’s decline is over,” he added.
The remarks sound reminiscent of what he would say at his campaign rallies.

headline: Layoffs to hit IRS as DOGE targets tax collections
content: The Trump administration is expected to begin laying off thousands of employees at the Internal Revenue Service, six people briefed on the matter said, as billionaire Elon Musk’s team begins to target tax collections. Treasury officials have discussed laying off roughly 9,000 employees still in their probationary period as part of broader dismissals across the government of recently hired workers, according to the six people who spoke on the condition of anonymity to reveal internal conversations. That number could not be immediately confirmed, and spokespeople both for the IRS and Treasury declined to comment. The cuts could start as soon as Friday. The layoffs are likely targeting tax collection, several of the people briefed on the matter said. Indeed, associates of Musk’s team are beginning to meet with high-ranking IRS officials about what could prove dramatic changes to the tax agency. Gavin Kliger, a software engineer now working at the IRS, met with Ken Corbin, the IRS’s chief of taxpayer services, and Heather Maloy, the agency’s top enforcement official, during his first day at the agency’s headquarters Thursday, according to several of the people familiar with the meetings. Republicans have long aimed to shrink the tax agency and were particularly incensed by the Biden administration’s push to hire thousands of new IRS agents to increase tax enforcement and collections. The cuts to federal personnel are likely to weaken the Biden administration’s efforts to bolster the IRS, though to what extent remains uncertain. The tax agency grew by about 10 percent last year, as its ranks swelled from roughly 90,000 employees in fiscal year 2023 to 100,000 employees this fiscal year. The IRS has said publicly that personnel critical to the tax filing season are ineligible for the “deferred resignation” plan that encouraged federal personnel to quit. That has fueled speculation that the cuts to IRS personnel will be concentrated among the agency’s tax collection staff, which could reduce the amount of revenue brought into federal coffers even as Musk calls for a reduced deficit. “It’s quite distressing, because the Biden administration made serious efforts to bolster enforcement. I think all of that is in jeopardy now,” said Steve Rosenthal, who served as a senior fellow at the Tax Policy Center, a nonpartisan think tank. “Stripping the IRS of resources is a windfall for those who like to game the system, and those are the most sophisticated and richest taxpayers.” Congressional Republicans are likely to welcome DOGE’s changes to the IRS. On Thursday, Rep. Jason T. Smith (R-Missouri), chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, wrote a letter to IRS’s acting commissioner blasting the $80 billion funding increase for the tax agency, among other measures. “President Trump has shown in his first three weeks that he meant what he said during the presidential campaign. Our government has not been working effectively for the American people, and it needs to change,” Smith’s letter states. Congress had given the IRS $80 billion over 10 years through the 2022 Inflation Reduction Act, but Congress rescinded $20 billion of that. Within the agency, the impending job cuts are being met with dread, both for individuals and the health of the tax system. The vast majority of Treasury employees work for the IRS. IRS employees cheered the Biden administration’s funding boosts, which yielded almost immediate performance and IT improvements. Now rolling those back — and cutting thousands of freshly hired employees — could send the agency into a tailspin in the middle of filing season. “It’s going to be like going off a cliff immediately,” said David Carrone, a revenue agent and president of the Louisiana-Arkansas National Treasury Employees Union chapter. Isaac Arnsdorf contributed to this report.

headline: Education Dept. launches investigation into Maine over transgender policies
content: The Education Department announced Friday that it was launching an investigation into a Maine high school and the state’s education agency, after a tense exchange between President Donald Trump and Maine Gov. Janet Mills (D) over transgender students. Earlier in the day, Trump warned during a session with the Republican Governor’s Association that Maine risks losing federal funding if it continues to allow transgender students to participate in girls’ sports, despite his executive order aiming to ban that. Mills responded: “We’re going to follow the law, sir. We’ll see you in court.” On Friday, the Education Department’s Office for Civil Rights announced an investigation. “Maine would have you believe that it has no choice in how it treats women and girls in athletics — that is, that it must follow its state laws and allow male athletes to compete against women and girls,” Craig Trainor, the Education Department’s acting assistant secretary for civil rights, said in a statement. “Let me be clear: If Maine wants to continue to receive federal funds from the Education Department, it has to follow Title IX.” Mills responded promptly saying the state was standing firm. “If the President attempts to unilaterally deprive Maine school children of the benefit of Federal funding, my Administration and the Attorney General will take all appropriate and necessary legal action to restore that funding and the academic opportunity it provides. The State of Maine will not be intimidated by the President’s threats,” Mills replied in a statement.

headline: Judge forces lawyers for fired inspectors general to withdraw TRO request
content: Lawyers for eight inspectors general suing the Trump administration over their firings last month were forced by an angry federal judge to withdraw their motion seeking a temporary restraining order. Judge Ana C. Reyes of the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia tore into the attorneys for the plaintiffs in a brief but heated hearing on Friday afternoon. Reyes demanded to know why the plaintiffs’ attorneys waited 21 days after the firings to file their lawsuit, only to then seek emergency same-day relief. She ticked off the list of emergency actions that have flooded the federal dockets and then limited the attorneys to “yes” and “no” answers. She also objected to the plaintiffs’ counsel comparing the facts of their case to those of Hampton Dellinger, the fired head of the Office of Special Counsel who sued the Trump administration last week. Dellinger argued in his complaint that his termination violated a law that shields the leaders of independent agencies from removal by the president. The inspectors general, however, are arguing that their firing was illegal because Trump did not give Congress 30 days’ notice of his decision as required by law. After forcing the plaintiffs to withdraw their motion for a temporary restraining order, the parties agreed to an expedited schedule. The government must reply to the lawsuit by Feb. 21. “Why on earth this could not have been decided in a five-minute phone call is beyond me,” Reyes said. She said she considered sanctioning the plaintiff’s attorneys but had more pressing matters on her docket.

headline: As Bondi takes over Justice Dept., official pledges no revenge on FBI agents
content: Pam Bondi was sworn in as the nation’s 87th attorney general Wednesday, inheriting a Justice Department roiled by recent staffing shake-ups and under pressure from President Donald Trump to remake a federal law enforcement apparatus he has denounced as “weaponized” against conservatives. She took the oath of office just hours after the department’s interim leaders sought to assure thousands of FBI agents who had worked on cases tied to the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol that they were not in imminent danger of being purged. Read the full story

headline: House speaker suggests Democratic votes could be needed on debt ceiling
content:
Speaker Mike Johnson (R-Louisiana) hinted that the GOP-led Congress may have to rely on Democrats to raise the debt ceiling this year in an interview during the House GOP retreat in Doral, Florida.
Though Johnson and many Republicans would like to raise the debt ceiling with only Republican votes, the speaker blamed the Senate’s 60-vote threshold for making that goal difficult. “I think there’s some concern in the Senate that might be difficult to do on a partisan basis,” he said.
Senate Republicans hold 53 seats, meaning they need seven Democrats to agree on passing bills that require a filibuster-proof majority. Republicans are hoping to use and approve of a budgetary maneuver — often referenced as “reconciliation” — that would  lower the filibuster threshold to a simple majority to pass President Donald Trump’s agenda. Some House Republicans would like to tack the debt ceiling onto the reconciliation process — which is expected to address border security, energy and tax changes — because it could be passed with GOP-only votes. But it’s unclear whether the debt ceiling can be included under the strict budgetary parameters of reconciliation.
House Republicans privately say they will need Democratic help, too, given that many fiscal hawks have pledged not to support raising the debt ceiling unless there are substantial spending cuts.

headline: White House, in reversal, rescinds freeze on federal grants
content: The White House budget office on Wednesday rescinded an order freezing federal grants, according to a copy of a new memo obtained by The Washington Post, after the administration’s move to halt spending earlier this week provoked a backlash. In a memo dated Wednesday and distributed to federal agencies, Matthew J. Vaeth, acting director of the White House Office of Management and Budget, states that OMB memorandum M-25-13 “is rescinded.” Read the full story

headline: EPA puts 168 environmental justice staffers on administrative leave
content: Trump appointees at the Environmental Protection Agency notified staff members Thursday that they plan to close the Office of Environmental Justice and External Civil Rights, and place 168 of its employees on administrative leave. “Career staff made determinations on which Office of Environmental Justice employees had statutory duties or core mission functions,” EPA spokeswoman Molly Vaseliou said in an email. “As such, 168 staffers were placed on administrative leave as their function did not relate to the agency’s statutory duties or grant work,” she added. “EPA is in the process of evaluating new structure and organization to ensure we are meeting our mission of protecting human health and the environment for all Americans.” The Washington Post also obtained an internal email notifying some division employees about being placed on leave. One employee in the office, who spoke on the condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to comment publicly, said that staff members have felt various degrees of fear since Trump’s executive orders targeting diversity, equity and inclusion initiatives across the government. “It’s clearly an all-out assault on federal workers, and it’s an all-out assault on the most marginalized communities in the United States and across the world,” the staffer said. Read more about the action here

headline: Layoffs loom as Trump administration orders federal DEI workers on leave
content: President Donald Trump’s administration took aim at government DEI programs, ordering federal diversity, equity and inclusion employees to be placed on leave no later than Wednesday and for DEI offices to be closed down, according to a memorandum sent Tuesday by the Office of Personnel Management. The directive will eventually lead to these employees being laid off or reassigned. It followed executive orders on Monday in which Trump directed an end to what he called “radical and wasteful” federal government DEI programs. Read the full story

headline: Pentagon to fire 5,400 civilian employees in ‘initial’ purge
content: The Pentagon said Friday that it will fire about 5,400 civilian employees beginning next week in an “initial” purge of its workforce, as President Donald Trump’s hastily issued orders to shake up the Defense Department faced new scrutiny and officials scrambled to understand whether such actions could imperil national security. The announcement followed a day of uncertainty, as administration officials paused a plan to begin firings now while evaluating requests to retain thousands of other employees deemed essential. A senior Pentagon official, Darin Selnick, said in a statement late Friday that the Trump administration intends to cull its workforce by between 5 and 8 percent. With more than 900,000 civilian employees in the Defense Department, tens of thousands of people could be forced out eventually. Echoing a pronouncement made earlier by Trump’s defense secretary, Pete Hegseth, Selnick said in his statement that “it is simply not in the public interest to retain individuals whose contributions are not mission-critical.” “Taxpayers deserve to have us take a thorough look at our workforce top-to-bottom to see where we can eliminate redundancies,” Selnick added. The cuts are necessary, he said, “to produce efficiencies and refocus” the Pentagon on Trump’s national security priorities. The firings are not expected to target U.S. troops. The Pentagon oversees about 1.3 million active-duty service members and nearly 800,000 more who are in the National Guard and reserves. The cuts will come after Trump administration officials, coordinating with billionaire Elon Musk’s U.S. DOGE Service, have slashed thousands of employees elsewhere in the government as part of the president’s broad effort to dismantle the federal bureaucracy. The Defense Department’s civilian worker purge is beginning with probationary employees, those who have one to three years of experience or who recently were promoted, according to officials familiar with the matter, who like some others spoke on the condition of anonymity because of the issue’s sensitivity. That pool of people numbers between 50,000 and 55,000, officials said. After deliberations over the last day, the Pentagon has settled on firing about 10 percent of its probational employees, a defense official familiar with the effort said. A hiring freeze is expected to take hold next week, and administration officials plan to spend two to three months analyzing who else could be ousted, the official said. Supervisors throughout the department, the federal government’s largest, have spent days requesting of the new administration that certain employees should be spared because the work they do is vital to national defense. An email obtained by The Washington Post indicates that Trump officials ultimately decided they need more time to sort through those many cases. The message, sent Thursday night by Ruth Vetter, a lawyer in the Pentagon general counsel’s office, said that senior officials had informed human resources staff that “they should not initiate removals of probationary employees” on Friday because requests for exemptions citing mission criticality “are still under review.” Vetter’s email, labeled “PRIVILEGED AND CONFIDENTIAL,” warned that an employee’s past performance “must be viewed through the current needs and best interest of the government, in light of the President’s directive to dramatically reduce the size of the federal workforce.” Vetter referred questions to Pentagon spokesman John Ullyot, who did not respond to requests for comment. Among the agency’s probationary employees are hundreds of teachers who work for the Department of Defense Education Activity, a school system that educates about 67,000 students — mostly the children of service members — at military installations around the globe. One person familiar with the matter said that DoDEA officials were attempting to save teachers from Trump’s purge of the federal workforce, but it was unclear if the effort would be successful. A DoDEA spokesman declined to comment. At the Office of Naval Intelligence, which provides senior military officials with maritime threat assessments and related analysis, employees were called to a meeting Thursday at their headquarters in Suitland, Maryland, where they were told that all probationary workers would be terminated, said one intelligence analyst. The analyst went to work Friday expecting to be out of a job, but was informed that no further instructions had been received. “Don’t get your hopes up too much,” he said he was told. The analyst, an Air Force veteran, said about 60 people in his office could be fired, and voiced frustration that he and his colleagues are seen by DOGE officials as numbers on a spreadsheet. “Work is next to impossible right now,” the analyst said. “Morale is through the floor.” Coinciding with the civilian-worker purge, U.S. defense officials, acting on orders from Hegseth, have undertaken a sprawling effort to compile options for slashing about 8 percent from each armed service’s budget for each of the next five years. Doing so, Hegseth has said, could yield $50 billion in 2026 to be reinvested elsewhere in the Defense Department, including an expensive missile-defense shield that Trump has taken to calling “Iron Dome For America.” After news of Hegseth’s directive alarmed lawmakers and defense officials, the former Fox News personality sought to blame the news media for causing confusion about the administration’s efforts and portrayed his plan as a “reorienting” of the Pentagon budget away from “woke, Biden-era nonlethal programs” to “instead spend that money on President Trump’s America First, peace-through-strength priorities for our national budget.” “It’s not a cut,” Hegseth said in a nearly nine-minute video posted to social media on Thursday evening. “It’s refocusing and reinvesting existing funds into building a force to protect you, the American people.” But independent budget analysts said it is highly unlikely that tens of billions of dollars per year can be targeted for reinvestment without slashing some major weapons programs and cutting the number troops in some of the services. Travis Sharp, a senior fellow at the Center for Strategic and Budgetary Assessments, said the fiscal 2025 budget under President Joe Biden included $162 million for diversity, equity and inclusion programs and $3.6 billion to build resiliency at Defense Department installations to counter climate change. Even if all of that money is removed from the budget and reprogrammed, he said, it’s a “drop in the bucket” at getting to $50 billion. To achieve such an ambitious goal, Sharp said, the Pentagon could retire older weapons programs, eliminate newer ones that remain in development, and shrink or shutter individual headquarters and agencies. Similar efforts have been undertaken before, Sharp said, including by Defense Secretary Robert Gates under President Barack Obama, but they still fell well short of Hegseth’s goals. “What they’re attempting is unprecedented in recent history,” Sharp said. Mackenzie Eaglen, a senior fellow at the American Enterprise Institute, said it will take an “all of the above” approach to cut that deeply into existing defense budget to fund new efforts. She noted that in a memo to senior Pentagon officials on Tuesday, Hegseth “walled off” 17 key priorities identified by the Trump administration — including missile defense, submarines, one-way attack drones and border security. So other areas will be especially vulnerable. “Look, the Defense Department reflects America,” she said. “The largest line item on the balance sheet of most corporations is labor. It’s people. There’s no workforce you can spare. They’re going to have to go after the defense civilian workforce as well as active-duty military end strength.” Another option the Trump administration could pursue, especially if it seeks to slash billions of dollars in future years for new priorities, is the closure of some existing military bases, Eaglen said. Such efforts — commonly known as base realignment and closure — have been politically unpopular, but could be appealing to Musk, she predicted. “There is a very compelling case for base closure,” Eaglen said. “If you kind of get into those weeds with people, you can make a rational business case. I actually think Congress could be compelled with a bully [defense secretary] and bully White House.” Warren P. Strobel contributed to this report.

headline: Judge temporarily blocks DOGE access to sensitive information at two agencies
content: A federal judge on Monday blocked Elon Musk’s U.S. DOGE Service from using private information collected by the Education Department and the Office of Personnel Management. U.S. District Judge Deborah L. Boardman in Maryland issued a temporary restraining order in a lawsuit led by the American Federation of Teachers to stop DOGE, which stands for Department of Government Efficiency, from accessing databases containing personal information on millions of Americans. She denied the union’s request to block DOGE from sensitive Treasury Department data because a preliminary injunction in a separate case achieved that goal. The order bars the Education Department and the Office of Personnel Management from disclosing personally identifiable information to DOGE affiliates at least until March 10. “This is a significant decision that puts a firewall between actors who we believe lack the legitimacy and authority to access Americans’ personal data,” said Randi Weingarten, president of the teachers union, which represents 1.8 million workers in education, health care and government. “When people give their financial and other personal information to the federal government — namely to secure financial aid for their kids to go to college, or to get a student loan — they expect that data to be protected and used for the reasons it was intended, not appropriated for other means,” Weingarten added. The Education Department did not immediately respond to requests for comment. Neither did DOGE. The lawsuit alleges that the Trump administration violated the Privacy Act by giving Musk’s team sensitive data for reasons beyond its intended use. DOGE has had access to databases that include home addresses, Social Security numbers and driver’s license numbers, among other information. The union says such access poses security risks. In addition to the AFT, the National Active and Retired Federal Employees Association and the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers are also plaintiffs in the lawsuit. They are joined by six individuals with sensitive data stored in federal systems, including military veterans who received federal student loans. The Education Department collects personal information to administer federal financial aid programs. DOGE had gained access to the department’s databases, including Federal Student Aid Partner Connect, the Financial Management System and the National Student Loan Data System. DOGE, according to previous Washington Post reporting, has been feeding data from across the Education Department into artificial intelligence software to probe the agency’s programs and spending. The effort is part of a push to slash spending and shrink the agency’s staff, as President Donald Trump seeks to dismantle the department. In the 33-page ruling, Boardman wrote that the government “never explains why” OPM and department personnel need this widespread access to Americans’ private information to carry out the overhaul. Boardman released the order days after a federal judge in a separate lawsuit refused to issue a restraining order to stop Musk’s team from accessing student data at the Education Department, saying there was no immediate threat in allowing it.

headline: Democrats settle on candidate for Rep. Stefanik’s seat
content:
Democratic Party leaders in New York’s 21st Congressional District have backed farmer Blake Gendebien for the anticipated special election to replace Republican Rep. Elise Stefanik, President Donald Trump’s pick to be U.N. ambassador.
The party chairs in the 15 counties that make up the district released a statement Tuesday unanimously endorsing Gendebien, calling him a political “outsider” who “embodies the voice and grit that distinguishes this district.”
The race would be an uphill battle for Democrats — Stefanik won reelection last year by over 20 percentage points — but it could serve as a gauge of Democratic enthusiasm in the first months of the second Trump term. New York Gov. Kathy Hochul (D) gets to schedule the special election once Stefanik is confirmed and gives up her seat.
Republican leaders in the district have not picked a candidate yet.

headline: Farmers sue USDA after agency deletes climate change data
content: A group of farmers and environmental nonprofits sued the U.S. Department of Agriculture, accusing the department of scrubbing data relating to climate change from its website and saying the move would hinder research and hurt farming initiatives. In a lawsuit filed Monday in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York, the Northeast Organic Farming Association of New York (NOFA-NY) and two environmental nonprofits, the Natural Resources Defense Council and the Environmental Working Group, accused USDA of deleting “climate-related policies, guides, datasets, and resources from its websites” in violation of laws on government transparency and agency action. The suit said the department’s actions hurt farmers who used the data to plan “agricultural decisions” and access funding, made it more difficult for climate researchers and advocates to do their jobs, and “deprived the public” of “vital information.” USDA websites include the Forest Service, Food Safety and Inspection Service, and Natural Resources Conservation Service. “USDA should be working to protect our food system from droughts, wildfires, and extreme weather, not denying the public access to critical resources,” said Jeffrey Stein, an attorney at Earthjustice, the legal group that filed the suit. USDA referred questions from The Washington Post to the Justice Department, which declined to comment on the lawsuit. Examples cited in the lawsuit include the Farm Service Agency taking down a webpage that told farmers how to apply for climate-smart agriculture and farm loan programs, and the Forest Service deleting an interactive map that allowed users to see where federal agencies have conducted climate change vulnerability assessments and learn more about them. Earthjustice said the data removal is “part of a trend” under the Trump administration, which has worked to dismantle climate protections and reverse federal policies aimed at fighting and measuring climate change. The suit also noted that the order to delete these materials came as farmers were already reeling from the Trump administration’s freeze of funding previously promised by USDA under programs aimed at promoting clean energy and sustainable agriculture — leaving many farmers on the hook for payments they never expected to make.
